{
  "translated_title": "[Daegu/Gyeongbuk] Daegu Catholic University President Kim Su-eop Suddenly Submits Resignation",
  "translated_text": "Daegu Catholic University President Kim Su-eop (金守業, 66) suddenly submitted his resignation after just 1 year and 4 months in office.

President Kim recently submitted his resignation letter to the school foundation (Catholic Archdiocese of Daegu's Seonmok Academy) and is known to hold a farewell mass on the morning of the 5th at the university chapel without inviting external guests.

Having taken office as president in September 2003, he failed to complete even half of his 4-year term and resigned at a time when university admissions work is in full swing, drawing attention to the background of his decision.

President Kim's resignation was so sudden that even faculty members holding administrative positions at the university headquarters were unaware of it in advance.

One administrative faculty member said, "In a situation where the Ministry of Education is strongly demanding university structural reform, President Kim may have decided to resign due to conflicts with the foundation."

Another professor stated, "There is almost nothing officially known about the background of his resignation," and "Given that he is holding only a farewell ceremony rather than both farewell and inauguration ceremonies, it can be presumed that conflicts arose related to his presidential duties."

The foundation plans to select a successor president soon."
}

{
  "translated_title": "Lawyers and Tax Accountants Also "Real Estate Spouses"",
  "translated_text": "Office worker Mr. Kang (35) is considering taking a real estate auction course. Thinking that having more knowledge would allow him to invest properly, he chose 'building real estate knowledge' as his New Year's goal.

Like Mr. Kang, more and more people are knocking on the doors of various real estate education courses to increase their financial investment knowledge.

Not only ordinary people, but also real estate agents, lawyers, and tax accountants are frequenting real estate education venues to differentiate themselves in increasingly fierce competition.

▽Diversified Education Courses = As the real estate market has been booming for the past few years, real estate education courses have also developed. Not only seminars and free lectures conducted by real estate information providers, but also department store education centers and university continuing education institutes are offering real estate-related courses.

The fields covered have also diversified to include not only real estate agent courses, but also consulting, auctions and public sales, land, financial investment, funds and indirect investment products.

Education periods also vary from one day to eight-month programs. Recently, there has been a particular increase in courses teaching practical investment techniques such as auction or public sale processes. Previously, there were many courses related to certifications or theory such as real estate agent courses, but recently practical investment analysis courses have increased.

Lawyers and tax accountants also attend classes in legal real estate agent courses conducted at places like Kyonggi University's Continuing Education Institute. This is to learn methods for analyzing real estate value based on data and provide differentiated services to clients.

Unlike studying alone, entering an education program has the advantage of being able to build networks with people interested in real estate.

▽Must Assess Lecture Quality in Advance = Many real estate-related lectures are also conducted at private hagwons. In such cases, it's important to assess the lecture quality by utilizing free trial opportunities. For long-term education programs, seeking advice from people who have previously taken them is also a method.

If you're taking a real estate-related course for the first time, choosing a course that teaches practical financial investment techniques is a good strategy to avoid losing interest.

Ham Young-jin, Information Team Manager at My Home Information Service, said, "Even if they're similar education programs, the lecture content, tuition fees, and course duration may differ, so it's good to carefully compare these in advance."

Reporter Heo Jin-seok jameshuh@donga.com

University Continuing Education Institute Spring Semester Real Estate Courses

Textbook fees may be required separately from tuition. Registration closes on a first-come, first-served basis.

Source: My Home Information Service"

{
  "translated_title": "[Gifted Education] Blind faith in IQ is "NO"... Creativity is the criterion for giftedness",
  "translated_text": "Fifteen middle school students from Seoul National University's Science Education Institute for the Gifted's 'Information Gifted Class' are practicing programming with robots in a classroom at Seoul National University's College of Education on the 5th. Reporter Kim Mi-ok

○ Intellectual stimulation is important until elementary 3rd grade

Experts believe that high intelligence or early mastery of reading and mathematics does not necessarily make one gifted.

Criteria and identification methods for giftedness vary by country and scholar, making it difficult to define with a single standard. Therefore, experts recommend that when a child shows creative ability or interest in a specific field, parents should seek consultation at specialized institutions.

The proportion of gifted education recipients varies by country: the United States 1-15%, the United Kingdom 5-10%, Israel 3%, Australia 1%.

Gifted education selection methods may differ depending on the educational institution. However, in public education, gifted education programs are not provided before elementary school 3rd grade. Until this time, it is considered more important to satisfy curiosity and provide intellectual stimulation.

In the past, gifted students were selected based on IQ or memorization ability, but nowadays the trend is to focus on the ability to recognize and solve problems from new perspectives, along with inquiry skills, critical thinking, concentration, and cooperation.

Gifted education candidates are selected through a process of recommendation → creative problem-solving ability test → performance assessment and interviews on experiments, etc. Appropriate identification methods and tools are used considering the student's characteristics, age, and educational domain (mathematics, science, arts and physical education, language).

Students hoping for gifted education can submit applications along with recommendation letters from school principals or supervising teachers when gifted education institutions announce their candidate selection. Gifted education institutions form selection review committees to conduct evaluations through interviews and experiments. Once gifted education institutions select candidates through this process, the final candidates are confirmed after undergoing final review by the provincial/metropolitan education office's Gifted Education Promotion Committee.

○ Criticism of 'uniform testing' also raised

Busan Science High School, a science gifted school, conducts first-stage selection through document screening and in the second stage selects approximately 1.5 times the admission quota by evaluating creative problem-solving abilities in mathematics and science fields.

Then it conducts a 3-night 4-day science camp to closely examine applicants' giftedness. This is to evaluate comprehensive inquiry performance abilities through various scientific activities. The camp also evaluates report writing and presentations, with final selection made through in-depth interviews.

Admission eligibility is not limited to 3rd-year middle school students, so in the 2005 academic year entrance exam, 2 and 22 students who were 1st and 2nd-year middle school students respectively also passed.

Most gifted education institutes and gifted classes under regional education offices also select students in the order of: 1st stage school principal recommendation, 2nd stage giftedness identification test (written exam), 3rd stage interview (or oral exam). For giftedness identification tests, most regions except Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education use test papers developed by the Korean Educational Development Institute [KEDI].

Hagwon education companies implementing gifted education are also selecting gifted students using self-developed methods or gifted identification methods introduced from foreign countries.

However, experts raise questions about hagwon education companies' testing methods, noting that in the case of young children, it is a period when it is difficult for children to express their potential and abilities.

Additionally, there is criticism that in some cases, objectivity is lacking as giftedness is determined through uniform test papers."
}

{
  "translated_title": "Too bothersome... Too dangerous... Buying 'volunteer service certificates' with money",
  "translated_text": "《High school students who are required to complete a certain number of volunteer service hours for college admission are often found to be fulfilling this requirement through improper means. The minimum mandatory volunteer service hours are 20 hours per grade level, totaling 60 hours. However, to apply for special admissions tracks at some universities based on volunteer service, students must complete more than 100 hours. As a result of this newspaper's investigation, it was confirmed that some students purchase volunteer service records with money or have them approved through various improper methods.》

The most common method of obtaining volunteer service certificates is to ask familiar public service workers or street cleaners to multiply volunteer service hours several times over.

Parents also give public service workers or street cleaners a few packs of cigarettes' worth of money to obtain volunteer service confirmation documents for their children who never actually performed the service.

Mr. Kim (22), who works as a public service worker in Incheon, confessed: "Following orders from a supervisor who received requests from church members, I once issued blank certificates in bulk by simply stamping them."

The volunteer service methods directly implemented by some schools in Seoul are equally lax.

In the case of 'checking neighbors' gas safety,' residents are reluctant to have students conduct safety inspections, making it ineffective. As a result, students simply collect 8 confirmation stamps from relatives or acquaintances claiming they received safety inspections, filling 8 hours of volunteer service time.

'Collecting coins of love,' where students collect coins by going around classrooms with donation boxes and receive 2 hours of volunteer service credit, is also a meaningless program since it's impossible to know if students contribute their own money.

'24-hour hunger experience' is also intended to give 8 hours of volunteer service credit for collecting money saved from food by fasting for a day, but since there's no supervision, some cases involve students paying money without actually fasting.

Some boarding hagwons operating during vacation periods collect money from students, donate it as sponsorship funds, then obtain volunteer service certificates from orphanages and other institutions on behalf of students. This is explained as a strategy to attract students.

The reason volunteer service has become nominal is primarily because it doesn't align with the current college entrance exam system, according to unanimous observations from frontline school teachers and volunteer center officials.

The majority of academic high school students are busy with hagwon education and private tutoring not only on weekdays but also on weekends, making it difficult to perform 20 hours of substantial volunteer service per year.

Even students seeking to apply for special volunteer service admissions tracks find it difficult to spare study time for volunteer work because they must also focus on their school records.

Kim Hyung-jin, secretary general of the 'School-Loving Association,' said: "To qualify for special admissions, students must complete at least 100 hours of volunteer service by their second year of high school, which is impossible without volunteering every week. This is why cases of purchasing volunteer service records with money emerge."

A teacher at Seoul's A High School said: "Students and parents tend to avoid meaningful work like helping disabled people or elderly people living alone, considering it difficult and dangerous."

There's also a structural problem where social welfare institutions and public agencies have no work for students because they concentrate their efforts during vacation periods.

Jeong Hee-seon (42), director of the Seoul Seocho-gu [a district in Seoul] Volunteer Center, suggested: "There's a need to establish a computer network system that identifies when and where students want to volunteer and connects them with the human resources needed by public institutions and social welfare organizations."

Reporter Jeong Se-jin mint4a@donga.com

▼"90% of recorded content is fake, but we pretend not to know for college admissions"▼

"80-90% of volunteer activities recorded in student records are hollow content."

Teacher Choi (47) from Seoul's A High School, who has been volunteering with students at orphanages in the Gangwon [a province in South Korea] region for 13 years, expressed regret that students' volunteer activities have greatly deviated from their original purpose.

Teacher Choi began volunteer work in 1992 when he started visiting this orphanage to give the love he couldn't give to his daughter who died of heart disease.

Then in 1996, when a policy was announced that volunteer activities would be reflected in college admissions, parents and students flocked to the orphanage Teacher Choi had been visiting and began volunteer activities by making donations. After becoming a full-time teacher in charge of volunteer activities, he always felt bitter watching the volunteer service system degenerate into a means for college admission.

Teacher Choi said: "Some students bring certificates claiming they volunteered for 2-3 days or more without even visiting the orphanage. The reality of having to pretend not to know despite knowing the truth because of college admissions is painful."

Teacher Choi criticized the education system that has reduced volunteer service to a tool for college admissions.

"There's insufficient time to do volunteer work and limited places available, so students trying to compensate for poor school records through volunteer service have no choice but to bring fake volunteer service certificates."

He said: "Volunteer service hours should be made realistic so as not to burden students, and volunteer centers and schools should thoroughly manage students' volunteer service situations.""
}

{
  "translated_title": "[Elementary School Test Revival] 'Helps Improve Student Performance' vs 'Concerns About Fueling Hagwon Education'",
  "translated_text": "Students taking the Basic Academic Skills Diagnostic Assessment administered annually to third-grade elementary students are earnestly solving problems. Dong-A Ilbo archive photo

The Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education's 'Academic Achievement Enhancement Plan' aims to raise academic performance among elementary, middle, and high school students, but there are reactions that the expansion of essay-type assessments does not consider the burden on teachers.

While the basic intent and direction are correct, criticism is emerging that it lacks practicality and shifts responsibility to frontline schools under the pretext of autonomy, being mindful of opposition from teacher organizations.

The education office's grade management guidelines stipulate that essay-type assessment questions should be evaluated by two teachers for objectivity, but this is not being well-observed even now.

Hwang Yong-ryeon, academic affairs director at Seoul's Yangjae High School, said, "It's desirable to strengthen essay-type questions to improve thinking and expression skills," but added, "However, if essay-type assessments increase to 50%, the workload burden on teachers will be excessive, making proper evaluation difficult."

Moreover, as seen in the recent incident of homeroom teachers filling out answer sheets on behalf of students, schools' school records management is not receiving trust, and with the increased weight of school records in university admissions starting from the 2008 academic year, grade-related disputes could arise.

Park Hye-sook (44, female), who has a third-grade middle school child, said, "If essay-type questions increase, scores could vary depending on the teacher," adding, "To avoid grade disputes, simple multiple-choice questions would be more reassuring for parents."

Parents generally welcome the revival of regular exams in elementary schools and improvements to grade report notification methods. Until now, they couldn't properly know their children's academic levels, leading to anxious psychology that made them rely more on hagwon education.

However, KTU (Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union, a left-leaning teachers' organization) criticized that "academic achievement enhancement measures centered on 'evaluation' will distort elementary school curricula and bring about hagwon education overheating."

In response, the metropolitan education office stated that public education can also raise academic achievement through measures such as △homeroom teacher responsibility guidance system for underperforming students △cyber home learning △substantiation of ability-grouped mobile classes.

Professor Park Bu-kwon of Dongguk University's Education Department said, "Currently there's a deformed situation where officially academic work is not emphasized while privately everyone clings to every single point," adding, "Since most are already using hagwon education, it won't increase further."

Reporter Lee Na-yeon larosa@donga.com"
}

```json
{
  "translated_title": "[Editorial] Be More Bold in 'Improving Academic Achievement'",
  "translated_text": "Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education Superintendent Gong Jeong-taek, who was elected after promising 'academic achievement improvement' in the education superintendent election last July, has announced specific implementation measures. The content includes reviving standardized tests for elementary schools that disappeared after 1997, increasing the proportion of essay-type exams in middle and high schools by more than 30% starting this year, and conducting academic diagnostic assessments for first-year middle school students. The plan is to expand competitive systems within schools and improve overall academic achievement through 'difficult exams'.

Due to the aftermath of overheated hagwon education, our education policy has been abnormally focused on how to reduce entrance exam competition. The current government has shown even more pronounced egalitarian tendencies. The new university admission system first applied to students entering high school this year is inviting 'abandonment of discrimination' by giving the same score to both the national 1st place and 48,000th place on the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam].

Schools without competition inevitably bring stagnation and complacency. In schools where tests and evaluations have disappeared, teachers have no reason to develop the motivation to teach earnestly. Even though students with poor basic academic skills should be gathered separately for supplementary learning to reduce dropouts, the reality is that even academic achievement assessments for this purpose cannot be freely conducted due to fear of teacher organizations. Easy multiple-choice questions at each school are becoming one cause of classroom collapse where students sleep at school and study at hagwons.

The Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education's academic improvement measures should serve as a stimulus to stagnant public education. Some may worry about the expansion of hagwon education, but finding ways to support poor students who cannot receive hagwon education through timely academic assessments is a more proactive and realistic alternative.

Superintendent Gong should also put into practice his promises to expand school choice and establish autonomous private high schools. While extreme competitiveness in education must be prevented, the policy bias toward abandoning competition altogether has also been wrong. It is time to pursue harmony between the two. More bold policies are needed to inject vitality into stagnant school sites."
}

{
  "translated_title": "Last year's hagwon industry records first negative growth",
  "translated_text": "Last year, the hagwon industry recorded negative growth for the first time since related statistics began in 2000 due to economic recession and other factors.

According to Statistics Korea on the 10th, last year's production index for college entrance exam prep, computer, and other hagwon businesses (based on 2000=100) was 110.1, an 8.3% decrease from the previous year's 120.0.

The hagwon industry maintained positive growth until the previous year with increases of 5.7% in 2001, 7.3% in 2002, and 5.8% in 2003, but last year showed a decline for the first time since hagwon industry production statistics began in 2000.

Due to the poor performance of hagwons, overall educational services industry production also showed a 5.6% decrease last year.

Educational services industry production growth rates had been steadily growing until the previous year with 5.9% in 2001, 6.0% in 2002, and 4.6% in 2003.

A Statistics Korea official explained, "Due to economic recession, hagwon tuition increases, and EBS's [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] lectures, the number of students and working adults giving up hagwon attendance increased, leading to decreased tuition revenue for hagwons and poor performance in the hagwon and educational services industries."

Meanwhile, Statistics Korea decided to enhance the representativeness of survey results by including not only kindergartens and college entrance exam prep hagwons but also elementary schools, middle and high schools, and other formal educational institutions in the survey scope for educational services industry starting with the '2005 January Service Industry Trends' data to be released next month."

{
  "translated_title": "[Reader Forum] Revival of Elementary School Standardized Tests",
  "translated_text": "▼Measuring thinking skills, not rote memorization-based evaluation▼
The current system where teachers record students' academic achievement levels in sentences on report cards leaves room for different interpretations depending on who reads those sentences. Naturally, it becomes impossible to gauge students' objective abilities. Parents, unable to know their children's actual abilities and levels, naturally turn to hagwon education out of frustration. Although standardized tests disappeared from elementary schools in 1996, the hagwon education market did not shrink but actually expanded further. Standardized tests that objectively show academic achievement levels should be reinstated. However, it would be problematic to stop at simply evaluating through rote memorization and assigning scores and rankings as in the past. Development of techniques that can evaluate and measure various thinking skills is necessary.
Kim Min-o, university student, Majang-dong, Seongdong-gu, Seoul

▼Revival desirable to supplement weak subjects▼
At some point, 'morale-boosting' education that doesn't display grades has been implemented under the motto of not treating children according to their academic performance. Since report cards mostly contain 'nice words,' parents often have vague expectations that their children are simply doing well. If academic achievement levels were displayed as in the past, parents would accurately identify their children's weak areas and make efforts to supplement them. They say hagwon education is a problem if standardized tests are revived, but how many households currently don't use hagwon education? Rather than unconditional hagwon education where children do it because others do, standardized tests should be revived even if only to use hagwon education limitedly to supplement deficient areas.
Jang Hyo-young, housewife, Hyeonggok-dong, Gumi City, North Gyeongsang Province

▼Should help children accumulate diverse experiences rather than focus on grades▼
I remember seeing a phrase in a public service advertisement once: 'Aren't you more interested in what rank your child is rather than what class they're in?' It was probably an attempt to enlighten parents who are only interested in rankings. I think elementary school years are a time to have broader experiences and nurture dreams for the future, rather than ranking children by who studies well or poorly. Should children learn from the start that competing with others and being first is the best thing, before they even realize what they like or what they want to do? Making children obsessed with test scores from a young age is not right. I hope people will think once more about what is important and precious for children during their elementary school years.
Jo Jae-hyeon, university student, Hwawon-eup, Dalseong County, Daegu

▼Will this make them obsessed with test studying again?▼
They say standardized tests should be implemented because students' abilities cannot be gauged and to improve academic achievement, but I think this is because parents have left their children's education to schools and hagwon education while remaining as bystanders. If families supplement their children's weak subjects at home and show just a little interest, there shouldn't be major problems. These days, children often say they dislike vacations. This is because they're too busy attending multiple hagwons. I feel sorry for young students who cannot play joyfully and have been reduced to exam preparers. If standardized tests are revived, I can clearly envision young students suffering through test preparation until late at night. For children, it's more important to nurture their innocence through nature observation, experiential learning, and play with peers.
Lee In-suk, school teacher, Yonggang-dong, Sacheon City, South Gyeongsang Province

▽The next Reader Forum topic is the 'Internet tracking system development' controversy. The prosecution recently announced that it is developing an 'Internet crime suspect tracking system' that locates criminal suspects through Internet Protocol (IP) address tracking. The prosecution selected a contractor last December and plans to complete system construction by March this year. The explanation is that it uses resident registration numbers to send decoy emails to email accounts presumed to belong to criminal suspects, and when read confirmation occurs, it determines location through IP tracking.
The prosecution believes this will effectively respond to increasingly sophisticated crimes while minimizing the possibility of investigative information leaks. However, there are also concerns that the introduction of a new system could lead to privacy violations by state power."
}

{
  "translated_title": "Ministry of Education Announces Results of 'One Year of Hagwon Education Cost Reduction Measures'",
  "translated_text": "The Ministry of Education and Human Resources Development announced on the 16th that hagwon education cost reduction measures implemented since February last year have achieved results, including a reduction of 106,000 won [approximately $80 USD] in average monthly hagwon education costs for households watching EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) lectures. However, the Ministry of Education faced criticism for 'self-serving interpretation' as it presented figures with weak evidence, including estimates, as major achievements while releasing the results of measures pursued to mark the first anniversary of the '2·17 Hagwon Education Cost Reduction Measures' announcement.

▽Hagwon Education Cost Reduction Effects=According to a survey conducted by the Ministry of Education in November last year through mobile polling agency 'MBzon CNC' targeting 1,000 students and 1,000 parents each, hagwon education costs for households watching CSAT lectures decreased by 106,000 won [approximately $80 USD] (28%) from 377,000 won [approximately $285 USD] to 271,000 won [approximately $205 USD] per month.

Respondents who said they watched CSAT lectures comprised 58.2% of parents and 41.8% of students, with an average daily viewing time of 1.7 hours.

According to the survey, hagwon education costs were reduced nationwide after the implementation of CSAT lectures: 24.1% in major cities, 34.1% in small and medium cities, and 32.6% in township and rural areas. Even in Seoul's Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] area, costs reportedly decreased by 31% from an average of 540,000 won [approximately $410 USD] to 370,000 won [approximately $280 USD] per month.

▽Cooling of Special Purpose High School Overheating=The Ministry of Education announced that as part of measures to normalize special purpose high school operations under the hagwon education cost reduction measures, the admission competition ratio for foreign language high schools decreased from 3.80 to 1 last year to 2.57 to 1 for the 2005 academic year.

A Ministry of Education official predicted that 'hagwon education overheating phenomena caused by indiscriminate special purpose high school admission fever will be resolved.'

The Ministry of Education also evaluated that it contributed to resolving educational gaps by income level and region by providing personal computers to 3,100 students from low-income families and marginalized areas.

▽Self-serving Interpretation Draws Criticism=At a press conference on this day, the Ministry of Education announced that 'as a result of pursuing hagwon education cost reduction measures for one year, the number of hagwon students in the 2004 academic year decreased by approximately 12% compared to the previous year.'

Regarding the basis for the '12% decrease,' a Ministry of Education official responded that it was 'calculated internally based on the 8.3% decrease in hagwon revenue announced by Statistics Korea on the 11th and the 4.6% increase in hagwon tuition fees.'

However, there are criticisms that the decrease in hagwon revenue is largely due to prolonged economic recession, though the hagwon education cost reduction measures may have had some influence. In fact, even in the survey commissioned by the Ministry of Education, 27.5% of parents cited 'household income reduction due to economic recession' as the reason for reducing hagwon education costs.

Moreover, the Statistics Korea announcement encompasses all types of hagwon education institutions, not just hagwons targeting elementary, middle, and high school students, but also technical and vocational training hagwons.

▽Insufficient Effort in Result Analysis=The Ministry of Education had been actively pursuing hagwon education cost reduction measures under the leadership of then-Deputy Prime Minister for Education An Byeong-yeong one year ago in February last year.

It was also active in analyzing the effectiveness of measures, including surveying and announcing hagwon education cost reduction effects targeting parents of high school students nationwide in May and November.

However, the Ministry of Education did not present new survey results to mark the first anniversary of the measures announcement. The performance announcement on this day was merely a rough compilation of past data. This amounts to turning away from efforts to overcome problems in future hagwon education cost reduction measures by distinguishing between what was done well and what was done poorly.

Related to this, some are raising concerns that the Ministry of Education's commitment to hagwon education cost reduction measures, which had been a priority project of the previous minister, may have cooled since Deputy Prime Minister An was dismissed."
}

{
  "translated_title": "'Easy-water CSAT Math B'… Grade inflation leaves science track students in 'mental breakdown'",
  "translated_text": "Chaos in 12th grade classrooms after CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] preliminary scoring
'Grade 1 cutoff' English 98 points - Korean B 91 points… Top-tier university early admissions for science track
Must get only 2-3 questions wrong combined in Korean-English-Math for safe zone… Teachers say "Can't get a feel for it due to lack of differentiation"

In this year's College Scholastic Ability Test, it appears that Math B will require a perfect score to receive Grade 1. With both math and English being unprecedentedly easy, students who compared preliminary scoring results at schools and hagwons on the 14th expressed dissatisfaction with the 'easy-water CSAT' [slang for an extremely easy exam] that lacked differentiation. Science track students in particular complained, saying "It's become difficult to even meet the minimum academic requirements for early admissions," and "When the CSAT is made too easy, it actually makes things harder for students."

○ Only perfect scorers get Grade 1 in Math B
According to grade cutoff scores estimated by college admissions companies, the Grade 1 cutoff for Math B is 100 points, with Grade 2 cutoffs at 95-97 points. Compared to last year's Grade 1 at 91 points and Grade 2 at 85 points, the grade cutoffs have risen abnormally. Ji Yun-gu (18), a student at Seoul Jungang High School who received Grade 1 in math, said, "I felt Math B was easy and I did get everything right, but I really didn't expect the Grade 1 cutoff to be a perfect score."

Since English has a Grade 1 cutoff of 98 points, getting one or more 3-point questions wrong immediately drops you to Grade 2. Korean A, which science track students mainly take, also has an estimated Grade 1 cutoff of 96 or 97 points, so you can only guarantee Grade 1 by getting everything right or missing just one question. Taking this together, science track students would need to get only two or three questions wrong combined across Korean-English-Math to stably meet the minimum academic requirements for early admissions at top-tier universities.

Kim Do-hwan (19), a repeat test-taker [a student retaking CSAT after high school graduation] aiming for medical school, said, "I got Grade 2 in Korean, Grade 1 in math, and Grade 2 in English, so these aren't scores that would get me into medical school through regular admissions, so I'm banking everything on early admissions." He added, "I've applied to medical schools at Korea University, Kyung Hee University, and Sungkyunkwan University through early admissions, but I'm worried I might not meet the minimum academic requirements because the CSAT was made too easy." Lee Hu-seung (18), a 3rd year student at Baejae High School, said, "My raw scores came out higher than practice tests enough to receive Grade 1 in all of Korean-English-Math, but I was shocked because the grade cutoffs were also high," adding "My friends are all confused too, saying they don't know what level constitutes doing well."

○ Teachers say "College guidance is overwhelming"
12th grade teachers who compiled students' preliminary scoring results unanimously agreed that college guidance has become too difficult due to the CSAT's lack of differentiation.

An Yeon-geun, a teacher at Seoul Jamsil Girls' High School, said, "For science track, medical school enrollment increased this year so the passing scores will likely drop compared to last year due to top students being dispersed, but the CSAT was too easy so I can't get a feel for it." She added, "For liberal arts, Korean has differentiation and the admissions landscape isn't much different from last year, but for science track, college guidance seems like it will be difficult."

Lee Seong-gwon, representative of the Korean Education Policy Teachers' Alliance (Seoul Daejin High School), said, "The difficulty of Korean and math came out so differently from the practice evaluations that students got angry saying 'If this is how it's going to be, why do we take the June and September practice evaluations?'" He added, "I agree with the long-term policy direction of making the CSAT easier, but all the college guidance teachers around me are perplexed about this year's CSAT, which has the worst level of differentiation in history."

Students poured out grievances such as "You've been creating the CSAT for years now, can't you still control the difficulty?"   "translated_text": "[CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] Test Writing Must Change] <Part 1> Let's Change the Writing System First

Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation Can't Find the 'Answer'

The Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation on Jeong-dong Street in Jung-gu, Seoul, has fallen into a dilemma following this year's CSAT English test writing error, which came after last year's CSAT world geography writing error. The evaluation institute is known to have internally decided to recognize multiple correct answers. Reporter Hong Jin-hwan jean@donga.com

The College Scholastic Ability Test [CSAT], which began in 1993, has continuously been embroiled in test writing error controversies. Each time, the issues were glossed over with stopgap measures, but following last year's world geography question error and this year's clear errors in CSAT, experts point out that comprehensive surgery is needed. In particular, the rushed test writing time and review process, and the barriers between writing and review teams are pointed out as fundamental causes that will repeatedly produce errors unless surgery is performed this time.

○ Hasty Test Writing and Poor Review

The 'short-term retreat-style test writing' system is pointed to as the biggest cause of poor test writing. For this year's CSAT as well, 316 CSAT test writers including professors and teachers went into retreat at an undisclosed location for a month starting in October to begin test writing work. They started creating problems with about a month left until CSAT. During this period, test writers must create problems while staying within the curriculum and maintaining a 70% connection rate with EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials and questions. After completing this, they must also go through the process of examining commercial reference books, problem sets, and hagwon materials to check if there are any similar questions.

Compared to the American SAT system, which creates many problems in advance using a test bank method, this is pointed out as being no different from hastily improvising problems before the test. The structure inevitably produces errors because test writers are assembled every year just before CSAT and problems are created in a short period.

Not only test writing but also the post-test review process proceeds breathlessly. When test problems are disclosed to test-takers and the media and error suspicions are raised, the evaluation institute must gather these, go through expert review and academic consultation, and finalize the correct answers. An evaluation institute official said, "Since score calculation, score report distribution, and each university's regular admission process are lined up afterward, we essentially have to finish review and confirmation within ten days."

As the evaluation institute is an organization, if it admits errors, it cannot avoid responsibility such as the institution head's resignation. This aspect is also one reason why errors are not admitted until the end. In the case of last year's CSAT world geography problem, admitting the error after a full year caused even greater confusion.

For this reason, experts point out the need to change the CSAT and college admission process periods. They suggest giving sufficient time between each stage of CSAT, score calculation, error review, and college admission processes. Lim Seong-ho, CEO of Haneul Education, said, "Realistically, the schedule is so tightly packed that proper review and error correction are difficult," adding "Since it's difficult to postpone university admission schedules, improvements such as moving CSAT up by one to two months from the current timing are necessary."

[Enlarge]

○ 'Professor-Dominated Test Writers Are the Problem' Criticism

The professor-centered composition of test writers is also pointed out as problematic. Of the 316 test writers responsible for this CSAT, over 75% are university professors, with the remainder being current high school teachers. When professors who form the core of test writers create questions, teachers serving as review committee members solve the problems, judge whether there are issues, and request question modifications.

A high school teacher who participated as a CSAT review committee member said, "Professors often don't know about high school students' intellectual level or learning degree." Regarding this year's Life Science II questions as well, schools and hagwon circles comment that "they twisted it too severely." A hagwon instructor in Seoul said, "Even hagwon instructors find it difficult to properly solve this year's Life Science II problems within the time limit (30 minutes)." Last year's Life Science II subject was written so easily that perfect scorers appeared in droves. Therefore, there's criticism that professors participating in this year's test writing only felt pressure to write more difficult questions than last year and created problems without considering test-takers' abilities. Although CSAT practice tests are conducted every June and September to adjust CSAT difficulty, professors reportedly don't give these much consideration.

It's also problematic that test-writing professors don't readily accept criticism from reviewing teachers. While professors have no choice but to accept feedback in subjects like mathematics where solutions and answers are clear, in subjects like science or English where there's room for debate, reviewing teachers' opinions are often ignored. It's also known that when teachers make criticisms due to the status difference between professors and teachers, test-writing professors often become very displeased.

Experts pointed out the need to change the personnel composition so that question writing and review are conducted equally. This is because proper verification is difficult to expect as long as the 'professor writing-teacher review' system continues. They suggest that both writing and review should consist of half professors and half teachers, or that review work should be handled by a second independent institution or external education-related organization rather than the evaluation institute."

{
  "translated_title": "Perfunctory Problem Verification... System That Reduces Experts to Mere Props Must Change",
  "translated_text": "[CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) Question Development Cannot Continue Like This] <Part 2> Short and Long-term Solutions to 'Reduce Accidents'

As errors in CSAT continue to recur, demands are growing to improve the question development and verification system, but changing the massive dinosaur that is CSAT is not a simple matter. Accordingly, experts point out that in the short term, verification should be strengthened to catch errors, while in the medium to long term, fundamental discussions about CSAT reform should begin.

CSAT replaced the scholastic achievement test with the goal of evaluating comprehensive thinking ability, but after continuing for over 20 years, it has been criticized for degenerating into a test of problem-solving techniques. Particularly in high school settings, CSAT subjects and scoring systems change frequently, and the abnormally high EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) linkage rate has led to criticism that 'CSAT is ruining high school education.' As diagnoses emerge that CSAT has reached its limits, demands are gaining momentum to convert CSAT into a qualification exam for high school graduation or university admission.

○ Enhanced Verification and EBS Reduction Are Urgent Priorities

The biggest reason last year's CSAT world geography question error was prolonged for over a year was that the process linking question development-verification-objection filing did not function properly. If it is inevitable to complete question development within tight deadlines under the current university admission schedule, verification and post-exam objection reviews must be conducted very strictly. However, the problem is that this process occurs among people connected through personal networks in academia. Particularly during objection review processes, the Ministry of Education and Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation [KICE] often make political judgments first, then reduce experts from specific academic societies to mere props. In the world geography case, just one day after KICE asked two academic societies for their opinions, these societies sent back replies saying 'no problems found' without even gathering member opinions.

Accordingly, demands are high to establish a dual system that completely separates question development and verification. However, unlike Korean, English, and mathematics, the realistic limitation is that it is difficult to construct dual personnel pools in elective subject areas where expert groups are small. For this reason, some teachers and professors are even proposing alternatives to involve test-takers who achieved top-tier CSAT scores within the past 1-2 years in the verification process, reasoning that they can catch errors from a test-taker's perspective.

The previous government's decision to raise the EBS linkage rate to 70% in an attempt to reduce CSAT hagwon education also needs to be corrected. The side effect of textbooks disappearing from senior year classrooms while students memorize only EBS materials is worsening daily. Lee Seong-kwon, a teacher at Seoul Daejin High School and representative of the Korean Education Policy Teachers' Coalition, pointed out that "the Ministry of Education's adoption of CSAT's EBS linkage policy was an anti-educational measure that further solidified one-way knowledge injection and problem-solving education."

Moreover, EBS materials are inevitably error-prone because they are created in short periods compared to textbooks and have simpler verification procedures. In the reality where CSAT question development committee members bring EBS materials into retreat centers to develop questions, EBS errors directly lead to CSAT accidents as seen this time.

○ Discussion of Qualification Exam Conversion Must Begin

More important than short-term prescriptions is fundamental improvement of the CSAT system.

In a reality where university admission competition is more intense than any other country, various problems inevitably arise when a state-administered relative evaluation exam has absolute influence on university admissions.

There are virtually no countries where national-level university entrance exams like CSAT dominate individual university admissions. In most cases, national-level exams are used as qualification exams for high school graduation or university admission. France's Baccalauréat and Germany's Abitur, which serve as both high school graduation and university entrance exams, are representative examples. These exams do not trigger blood-draining competition like CSAT because they divide pass/fail based on certain score thresholds.

In contrast, our CSAT adopts a 9-grade relative evaluation system, so instead of just needing to exceed a certain score, students must engage in infinite competition within the entire test-taking population. Because universities cannot conduct separate entrance exams due to the Three Prohibitions Policy (prohibition of university-specific exams, high school ranking systems, and contribution-based admissions), they set high CSAT weight ratios as an alternative, since CSAT has more credibility than school records [GPA]. This is why CSAT's influence is inevitably absolute.

Due to these problems, the Ministry of Education already attempted to convert CSAT into a qualification exam 10 years ago. In February 2004, the then Ministry of Education and Human Resources Development announced 'Measures to Reduce Hagwon Education Through Public Education Normalization,' forecasting complete qualification exam conversion starting with the 2008 CSAT. However, this policy was abandoned due to the lack of viable alternatives to replace CSAT and concerns that it could revive university-specific entrance exams.

Over the subsequent 10 years, CSAT question development errors became more frequent, and in situations where question bank methods cannot be adopted, creating new questions while avoiding previous exam questions has also reached its limits. To pursue CSAT qualification exam conversion again at this point, comprehensive reconstruction of the three major admission elements—school records, CSAT, and university-specific exams—must precede such efforts. To reduce CSAT's weight in admissions, how to evaluate school records and what range of university-specific exams to allow become important variables."
}

  "translated_title": "[Rijinonseol/Essay-writing Vitamin] Uncovering the Identity of Integrated Curriculum Essays (1)",
  "translated_text": "《Starting today, we will examine integrated curriculum essay-writing exams [a component of some university admissions], which have become a subject of interest for all of us. While this term frequently appears in the media, many people find it confusing and want to know exactly what it is. There are three or four similar terms: 'integrated curriculum essay-writing exam,' 'integrated curriculum essay,' 'integrated essay,' 'comprehensive essay,' etc. Do these terms refer to the same content, or do they have different meanings? We need to sort this out first.》

First, we can consider 'integrated curriculum essay-writing exam' and 'integrated curriculum essay' to be the same term. This is what we need to identify. The term 'integrated essay' may ultimately refer to the same content as integrated curriculum essay-writing exams, but it comes from a different context. 'Integrated essay' emerged when universities that previously administered language essays and mathematics essays separately decided to 'combine' them for various reasons. Language essays alone were already interdisciplinary within the humanities and social studies areas, and mathematics essays alone were already interdisciplinary within the mathematics and science areas.

The implication of integrated essays is that the scope of interdisciplinary integration has now expanded to encompass both the humanities/social studies areas and the mathematics/science areas in essay questions. This means that humanities essays will include elements evaluating mathematical thinking, and science essays will include elements evaluating humanistic writing. The term 'comprehensive essay' is an umbrella term that vaguely encompasses all the aforementioned terms. After the transition from the Academic Achievement Test to CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam), hagwons used expressions like 'integrated social studies' and 'integrated science' to reflect CSAT's interdisciplinary concept, and this expression was applied to essays. Ultimately, all these terms can be encompassed under the concept of integrated curriculum essay-writing exams.

Let's clear up one misconception about integrated curriculum essay-writing exams. Many people think that integrated curriculum essay-writing exams are a new type of essay, but this term does not refer to a peculiar form of new essay-writing exam. This is because essays have always been interdisciplinary by nature.

First, essays are not exams that focus on one subject and test knowledge of that subject—that is, they are not descriptive exams about a specific subject. In this respect, they are fundamentally different from the old university entrance exams. Ultimately, since students must integrate content learned from various subjects to solve given problems, essays are inherently interdisciplinary. From the early days when essay exams began, although slightly different meanings were assigned, the term 'interdisciplinary' has been used regarding essays. Therefore, when Seoul National University promoted integrated curriculum essay-writing exams last year, it should be understood not as an intention to introduce a new format, but as an intention to conduct exams faithful to the original nature and purpose of essays.

So what are integrated curriculum essay-writing exams? To answer this question, the term 'integrated curriculum' must be precisely defined. While these are not widely used terms, and it may seem like word play, intentionally distinguishing three concepts will help understand the integrated curriculum concept.

Let's compare the three terms: 'mixed curriculum,' 'integrated curriculum,' and 'convergence curriculum.' What differences exist?

First, mixed curriculum would refer to multiple subjects being combined in parallel. It would indicate a form where knowledge and content from various subjects are mobilized together. So, if we use the expressions 'physical combination' and 'chemical combination' metaphorically, it would be closer to the physical combination of subjects.

What is convergence curriculum? It's when the identity of each subject disappears and they are bound together as one, resulting in a more comprehensive subject with a new identity. This can be compared to the chemical combination of subjects.

So what is integrated curriculum? Of course, it can be used at almost the same level as convergence curriculum, but the concept we currently use remains somewhere between mixed curriculum and convergence curriculum. Unlike convergence curriculum, the identity of each subject does not disappear. However, rather than simply combining in parallel like mixed curriculum, it breaks down the barriers between subjects and enables internal communication between different subjects.

From the student's perspective, while learning initially occurs by subject, the learning content is not bound to individual subjects but transcends subject boundaries. In other words, it means studying integratively by applying what was learned in one subject to other subjects. Shall we look at an example? Students learn about 18th-century Korean society in Korean history class. However, rather than ending it with Korean history, when students learn about 18th-century Korean literary works in Korean language class and try to understand them by utilizing and applying what they learned in Korean history, integrated curriculum education occurs. Therefore, integration is something students must do themselves, not something teachers do, and education must cultivate such integrative ability.

From this context, we can see that the integrated curriculum approach aims to cultivate the ability to study independently—that is, self-directed learning ability. However, such independent study cannot be immediately achieved just by having a lot of knowledge. Critical and creative thinking ability is needed to integrate acquired knowledge and information to rationally solve given problem situations, which is why integrated curriculum essay-writing exams evaluate thinking ability.

We have already mentioned two core aspects of integrated curriculum essay-writing exams. First, they seek to evaluate self-directed learning ability. Second, to achieve this, they seek to evaluate thinking ability for problem-solving rather than knowledge. Adding two more characteristics reveals the full picture of integrated curriculum essay-writing exams. Third, among thinking abilities, particular emphasis is placed on evaluating creativity. Fourth, to properly evaluate thinking ability, process-centered evaluation is emphasized over result-centered evaluation. We will examine each of these four logically connected characteristics one by one to uncover the identity of integrated curriculum essay-writing exams.

Park Jeong-ha, Professor at Sungkyunkwan University's University College, Deputy Director of EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] Essay Research Institute"

{
  "translated_title": "[Opinion/Jo Yeon-soon] How Can Essay-Writing Be Taught Separately?",
  "translated_text": "There is an essay-writing exam fever in hagwon education. Particularly during this period after the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) has ended, most college entrance exam preparation students are said to be skipping school classes and busy preparing for essay-writing exams at hagwons. Due to this situation, an increasing number of schools are setting aside separate essay-writing periods for preparation.

When did essay-writing exams become part of college admissions? Instead of university-specific entrance exams, students began to be selected based on CSAT and high school GPA scores, but as this reduced discriminatory power, essay-writing exams began to be administered separately, and the weight of essay-writing exams is gradually increasing.

The reason universities emphasize essay-writing exams is to evaluate problem-solving ability, thinking skills, and students' own thoughts that cannot be judged by CSAT and high school GPA scores. Essay-writing exams go beyond the realm of simple writing. They are conducted to evaluate what students think about problems spanning multiple areas and whether they can logically develop their own thoughts. This includes critical thinking skills, creative thinking skills, and problem-solving abilities. It is difficult to cultivate critical thinking skills and creative thinking skills by teaching essay-writing separately from other subject education in an intensive manner.

I remember that when I graded college entrance essay-writing exams a few years ago, it was difficult to find students who wrote with their own thoughts. This is true not only in essay-writing but also in interviews. When I asked about their motivation for applying to our university or their motivation for choosing their major, few students expressed their own unique thoughts. Most students gave almost similar answers according to problem types as a result of training through short-term education.

Although it is fortunate that schools have belatedly stepped forward to provide essay-writing guidance on their own, the method of teaching it separately from other subject hours is not effective. Since thinking is about some object, techniques alone cannot be taught separately without content.

Thinking skills must be taught together with the content of subject education already covered in schools. If we reconstruct the curriculum to enable students to solve problems that occur in real life by relating them to subject content, rather than limiting ourselves only to knowledge within textbooks, we can not only motivate learning but also cultivate thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, and self-directedness.

{
  "translated_title": "[College Entrance Academy] Set specific goals for target schools and study plans...",
  "translated_text": "Students who received lower scores than expected on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) or failed in university-specific tests such as essay-writing exams or interviews must soon decide whether to become repeat test-takers [students retaking CSAT after high school graduation].

However, life as a repeat test-taker carries greater psychological burden than attending high school, and it's not easy to improve grades due to slumps and various temptations.

To have a successful repeat test-taking experience, one must have the will to break away from the protective framework of school, control time independently, and resist temptations from TV, games, internet, and friends.

Once you've decided to retake, you must properly understand changes in the 2008 academic year admission system and approach your repeat test-taking life accordingly to increase your chances of success.

○ Establish learning goals systematically

In the 2008 academic year college admissions, CSAT scores will be reflected in a grade system and essay-writing exams will carry greater weight, so it's most important to clearly determine your target school and department and improve your skills in weak areas.

For example, if a student who scored 72 points (3rd grade) on the Math 'Na' section of this year's CSAT wants to enter a university next year that requires 2nd grade or higher in Math 'Na' as admission criteria, it means they need to improve at least 12 points from their current level.

Particularly with grade system reflection, being short by just 1 point renders retaking ineffective, so it's necessary to study strategic subjects sufficiently to exceed the grade cutoff line.

The success or failure of retaking depends not on unconditionally relying on hagwon lectures, but on how much you master the lecture content yourself. It's good to set a goal of reviewing that day's learning on the same day and create specific weekly and monthly study plans.

It's also good to make an effort to correct about three bad habits from your three years of high school. Particularly, habits of being addicted to games or being lazy must be abandoned immediately from the moment you decide to retake. If you start your repeat test-taking life while maintaining bad habits, failure is as obvious as fire.

While focusing on supplementing weak subjects, you must never give up on Korean, English, and Math midway. If all three subjects have good scores, not only do application opportunities increase, but you can also gain more benefits such as bonus points.

Kim Yong-geun, evaluation director at Jongro Hagwon, said, "You must compare the scores and grades you received this year with grade-specific cutoff points and make detailed plans about how much time to invest in which subjects," adding "You must steadily build your skills by examining how much your scores improve in each subject through monthly mock exams."

○ Choose your own retaking strategy

After considering your level and final goals, it's also important to find suitable study methods such as self-study, subject-specific hagwons, comprehensive retaking classes, or boarding hagwons.

For students who are thorough in self-management even alone or have good overall grades but struggle with one or two subjects, it's good to supplement lacking subjects by taking online lectures or attending subject-specific hagwons. It's advisable to create specific study plans yourself and focus on advanced learning for subjects you're good at and intensive supplementary learning from the basics for lacking subjects.

Students who lack confidence in time management and have much higher learning efficiency when there are people around to help should attend comprehensive retaking hagwons. Comprehensive retaking hagwons conduct regular classes from 8 AM to 5 PM and have self-study or supplementary classes until 10 PM, which is not much different from senior year of high school.

Some hagwons can conduct efficient classes and establish systematic learning strategies by gathering students of similar levels through selection tests, which helps test-takers with significant psychological anxiety.

Boarding hagwons are suitable for students who lack learning motivation and want to escape various temptations to focus only on studying. This is because they help students concentrate only on studying through strict learning and life management in isolated learning spaces, and they take responsibility for guiding even supplementary classes or self-study after regular classes.

However, it should be noted that since dormitory supervisors manage all aspects of life and outings are permitted only about once a month, this may have reverse effects on test-takers who cannot endure dependent and strict lifestyles.

Lee Man-gi, evaluation director at Uway Central Education, said, "For successful retaking, regular living habits and learning motivation are most necessary," adding "In the early stages of retaking, rather than focusing unconditionally on problem-solving, it's better to understand principles by subject and establish the big framework."

Ji-woo (8, female, first grade at Gyeongdong Elementary School in Seoul), who entered the school gates with her small hands last March, will become a second-grader after winter break. Ji-woo, who was just young before, has grown taller and her thinking has matured compared to when she first enrolled. She has become quite a dignified 'student' who moves according to a daily schedule she created herself. Using Ji-woo's year as a mirror, here are some helpful tips for new students.

○ Excessive parental interest may backfire

Kwon says, "I directly helped with school studies at home but left other things to Ji-woo, which seems to have fostered her independence. Now that she's somewhat settled into a routine, I need to start paying attention to her studies from now on."

However, there are also cases where excessive parental interest in studies led to trial and error. Kim Hyun-kyung (35, Cheongdam-dong, Gangnam-gu [an affluent district in Seoul], Seoul) participated in group tutoring [과외] worried that her child might fall behind due to the flood of study-related information from around her, but soon gave up. The child was tired from managing both school life and tutoring, and the actual effects weren't significant. Kim emphasizes the importance of 'conviction,' saying, "If you emphasize studying too much when they're young, they might actually become distant from studying. Information should be used as reference, but parents must make the judgments and decisions."

Lee Kyung-min (35, Hyehwa-dong, Jongno-gu, Seoul) also shares, "Due to the burden of dual-career work, we had high dependence on hagwon education [사교육] from first grade, but in first grade, rather than studying, it's better to slowly explore overall life to see if the child is properly adapting to school life."

Parental role instructor Park Yong-ok (49, female) also says, "Excessive interest in children can interfere with a child's autonomy," adding, "In front of parents with vast information and their attempts to inject it, children can become strangers."

○ Enrollment is an excellent opportunity to change children's habits

Teacher Lim Young-ah (36, female, Apgujeong Elementary School in Seoul) emphasizes that elementary school enrollment is an excellent opportunity for children to change two types of habits.

First is helping them learn compromise and consideration by following the rules of group life in daily life, making them realize they are 'individuals within a community,' and second is the opportunity to change study habits by focusing on school education. Unlike hagwons that have many questions and require quick answers, schools emphasize process, so some children may find school studies bland or lacking content. However, the faster they adapt to school education, the more leisurely they can study as they advance to higher grades.

○ From senior first-grade parents to new student parents

Choi Yu-young (39, Hyeonjeo-dong, Seodaemun-gu, Seoul) advised, "After enrolling my child in school, I was entirely focused on school, wondering if they were doing well, but I learned that such parental attitudes can be stressful for children.   "translated_text": "The Supreme Court First Division (presiding Justice Jeon Su-an) ruled on the 6th in a wage claim lawsuit filed by 11 driving school instructors including Mr. Jeong against their employer, stating "longevity allowances must be included when calculating minimum wage," and remanded the case to the Seoul Northern District Court panel.

The court stated, "Longevity allowances are wages paid regularly at least once per month for prescribed working hours or working days, and are not wages of a nature to assist workers' livelihood or provide welfare benefits. Therefore, it is difficult to consider them as wages or allowances that are not included in 'wages for minimum wage application' (comparative wage standards) under the enforcement regulations of the Minimum Wage Act."

Mr. Jeong and others filed a lawsuit claiming 2-6.51 million won [approximately $1,500-4,900 USD] per person in unpaid wages, arguing that they received wages below the minimum wage while working as driving school instructors for 10 months to 4 years, and that their severance pay calculations were also incorrect.

The first and second instance courts ruled that irregularly paid longevity allowances could not be considered fixed wages, excluding them from ordinary wages when calculating minimum wage, and ordered the employer to pay 1.85-5.65 million won [approximately $1,400-4,300 USD].

The appellate court's judgment was that longevity allowances paid monthly at fixed amounts determined uniformly according to length of service, but with 10% deducted for each day of absence, were influenced by actual work performance and could not be considered fixed wages.

The Supreme Court had previously ruled in 2002 that longevity allowances paid regularly and uniformly should be viewed as fixed salaries and included in ordinary wages under the Labor Standards Act.

The Supreme Court stated, "The lower court confused wages for minimum wage application (comparative wage standards) with ordinary wages under the Labor Standards Act, and judged that this case's longevity allowances could not be included in comparative wage standards because payment amounts varied according to workers' actual working days and were not fixed wages, thus not qualifying as ordinary wages. This represents a misunderstanding of the scope of 'comparative wage standards' under the Minimum Wage Act.""

At Seoul O High School, about 600 students graduate each year, but every year 20% of students don't attend graduation ceremonies. Since graduates rarely come back later to pick up their diplomas, teachers worry every year about how to handle the diplomas.

Teachers say that the changing customs around graduation season make them acutely aware of the current state of school education. It's hard to find graduation ceremonies these days that turn into seas of tears when the lyrics "To my sister who received a shining diploma..." come to an end. Diplomas are no longer shining objects.

One teacher clicked his tongue, saying, "In the old days, people would roll up diplomas and carefully store them in tubes, worried they might get wrinkled, but now we have to call and plead with them to come pick them up."

There are two main surface reasons why students don't take diplomas seriously. One is college entrance exam failure. When students can't get into university or don't get accepted to their desired university, their wounded pride keeps them away from graduation ceremonies. This phenomenon is more severe in coeducational schools. Students who decide to retake the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] enter boarding hagwons early and struggle with books when graduation ceremonies are being held.

The other reason is overseas study programs or travel. Since college freshmen these days start preparing for employment from their first year, they want to do things they couldn't do before after college entrance exams are over. Some prospective high school students, having suffered from college entrance exam pressure, choose to go to hagwons when hagwon schedules for advanced learning overlap with graduation ceremonies.

However, teachers point out that students' individualistic tendencies and lack of sense of belonging to school are more fundamental reasons. Having spent more time at hagwons than at school, their sense of school as a 'community' has already faded. Also, students don't need to feel sad about parting with friends since they can contact them by mobile phone anytime even after graduation ceremonies end.

The parent generation, who used to hug friends and burst into tears just hearing graduation songs, would find it hard to understand today's students. When times change, social customs change too. But it's bitter that college entrance exam pressure, advanced learning, and collapsed community consciousness are accelerating such changes."

When meeting with people at universities, one comment that invariably comes up is "today's college students are pitiful." This is because as soon as they break through the complex college admissions process and enter university, they must immediately throw themselves back into studying to break through the job market difficulties.

This was a common comment regardless of whether it was a four-year university or community college, Seoul-area university or regional university. College students are supposedly buried in books at the library from dawn because of job preparation... When I asked, puzzled, various examples emerged.

Professor A from the English Literature department said, "Students' classroom attitudes have noticeably worsened over the past few years. He reported that the very students who slept during English class would grab TOEIC materials and run to the library as soon as class ended. Professor A diagnosed that the 'classroom collapse' phenomenon that worsened in the 2000s—where middle and high school students studied at hagwons [private academies] at night and slept at school during the day—seems to be continuing into universities.

Professor C said, "Some students nowadays prepare for jobs during humanities lectures, and when they hear that humanities has become important in interviews, they go looking for humanities special lectures," adding, "Their judgment according to TPO (time, place, occasion) seems to be declining."

Synthesizing these various examples, it seems a trend is emerging among college students where the quantity of studying has increased but the quality of academic work has declined. Professors identified college students' dependency and anxiety as the causes. Children who moved according to hagwon schedules following their parents' coaching from a young age have diminished ability to think about what they should do on their own even as college students. Their judgment about where to focus each moment and what they should be doing at any given time also becomes blurred. Since everyone says you need to build specs to get a job, they are driven by anxiety to move busily.

The polarization of self-direction among grown students is as concerning as the polarization of hagwon education [private supplementary education] among young students. The world is becoming more complex and fierce by the day, yet it seems like adults in name only—who lack the decision-making ability to break through this—are increasing."

  "translated_title": "A world that regards mothers' hearsay about college admissions as gospel... Trust in children should come first",
  "translated_text": "[Now it's about 'study power'] Expert column on 'study power'

A few days ago, I witnessed this scene at a cafe near a middle school. Five mothers had gathered and were having a heated conversation. "You can't write that kind of thing in the personal statement for foreign language high school admissions. They'll deduct points." "The math instructor at hagwon A behind the school has a bad reputation. The instructor at hagwon B is better because they're a KAIST [Korea's top science and technology university] graduate."

Even to a casual listener, this was information that only experts would typically know.

As the conversation intensified, the cafe door opened and another mother entered. All the mothers' gazes turned to her in unison. I understood why from their subsequent conversation. Her daughter was ranked first in her entire school.

When I counsel parents, I find that the world of mothers is largely divided into three categories. The first consists of mothers whose children are ranked first in their school or have entered Seoul National University. The second includes mothers who aren't 'mothers of first-place students' but are well-versed in college admissions information and share it with others around them. The rest are the ordinary majority of mothers.

The group that deserves attention is precisely the third category of mothers. They are always thirsty for college admissions information and often regard the information they hear from other mothers as essential 'gospel' for their children. They pour out college admissions information heard at cafes, social gatherings, and mothers' meetings onto their children without filtering it. Their children, who don't understand why, must bear all that pressure.

From an expert's perspective, this kind of information doesn't serve as 'medicine' in the long term. Korea has countless high schools and universities. College admissions change every year, and admissions strategies and study methods vary enormously. Sometimes even experts get confused.

What's important for parents is knowing their own child well. But many mothers place more importance on 'hearsay.' It's similar to giving a child with a cold digestive medicine, blood pressure medication, and even tongjinsotang [a traditional Korean herbal tonic].

Studying requires 'study power' as a foundation for good results to continue long-term. Study power is a kind of 'basic muscle' formed through students' individual abilities and their surrounding environment. It develops by consistently trusting your child, cultivating habits that allow them to study independently, and creating the right environment. The priority is increasing conversation time with your child and understanding what areas interest them and what methods they prefer. Only then will studying last long-term.

Yoon Dong-su, Director of Jinhaksa Youth Education Research Institute"
