  "translated_title": "Hallasan Mountain is in Pain",
  "translated_text": "Heavy rains and typhoons cause collapse of Baengnokdam's north wall… Concerns that circular crater could become horseshoe-shaped with one side broken open
Over 1 million climbers visit annually… Some smoke, drink alcohol, and dump trash carelessly
The north wall (within dotted lines) of Baengnokdam crater at Hallasan's summit continues to crumble. Hallasan is suffering from trash left by climbers, various natural disasters, and safety accidents. (Top photo) External view of the eroding north wall at Hallasan's summit. Jeju=Reporter Lim Jae-young jy788@donga.com

A type of cherry tree called wild cherry was in full bloom, and delicate windflowers shyly poked their heads up from the ground. Wheel-shaped primroses were at their purple peak, and thorny elaeagnus burst with yellow buds between sharp spines. Korean firs, which have been dying en masse due to climate change, are struggling desperately to spread life. While downtown Jeju was racing toward summer, the high elevations of Hallasan visited on the 17th were just beginning to experience spring.

Although spring had come to Hallasan's summit, scars were visible everywhere. After passing the Triangle Peak rest area (1,620m above sea level) on the Gwaneumsa course, fencing bent like taffy came into view. The fence installed to protect climbers from landslides and rockfalls had collapsed under the weight of winter snow. This nearly led to a major disaster. On the 19th, a large boulder struck the climbing trail. Hallasan National Park immediately prohibited access to the 2.5km section from Triangle Peak rest area to the summit.

Cracks and landslides are even changing Hallasan's appearance. Baengnokdam's north wall continues to collapse whenever heavy rains and typhoons strike. Predictions suggest that the circular crater shape will soon change to a horseshoe shape with one side broken open. Damage caused by climbers is also significant. Below the summit deck, plastic bottles and disposable lunch containers secretly dumped by climbers were abundant. Although access around Baengnokdam crater is restricted, climbers who ignore these restrictions are frequently spotted.

On the descent via the Seongpanak course, disturbing scenes were witnessed at the Azalea Field shelter as well. Lunch trash secretly dumped by climbers was visible in various spots, and some climbers secretly smoked cigarettes while avoiding park staff enforcement. Following 85 people last year, 21 people have been caught smoking through the end of last month this year. The Seongpanak course, which attracts about 36% of climbers among Hallasan's five climbing routes, experiences parking wars every weekend.

A Korean-American visitor (38, hagwon instructor) experiencing Hallasan for the first time said, "Although the course was somewhat monotonous, the crater, native plants, and strange rock formations were special. It was certainly worthy of being designated a World Natural Heritage site," but added, "However, I was somewhat disappointed to see climbers drinking alcohol at the summit and carelessly dumping trash." Hallasan attracts visitors from around the world including China, the United States, Russia, France, Italy, and Pakistan. They come to directly experience Hallasan, the core area of UNESCO [United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]'s natural science triple crown: World Natural Heritage site, Biosphere Reserve, and Global Geopark.

The number of climbers first surpassed 1 million in 2010 with 1.14 million, then recorded 1.13 million in 2012, 1.2 million in 2013, and 1.16 million in 2014. Kang Si-cheol, director of Hallasan National Park Management Office, said, "Hallasan is Korea's treasure. We should cherish and protect it, but climbing etiquette is below standard. There are many cases of people harming their bodies through reckless climbing. We must join forces to make it a famous mountain that people worldwide enjoy visiting, like China's Huangshan [Yellow Mountain].""

  "translated_text": "[Start Your Engine, Good Driving] <11> For Happy Driving by Female Drivers

47.6 out of 100 people. This is the percentage of women who hold driver's licenses (as of 2014). In other words, half of all women are qualified to drive. Compared to 4.9 out of 100 in 1990, this represents roughly a 10-fold increase. While the number of female drivers has grown, their traffic accident fatality rate is not as high as one might think. In 2011, the number of deaths per 100 traffic accidents involving female drivers (fatality rate) was 1.5, lower than the overall rate of 2.4. Seol Jae-hoon, a senior research fellow at the Korea Transport Institute, said, "Female drivers generally drive more safely, which is why their fatal accident rate is lower than that of men." However, the reality on the roads is different. Many women still face serious threats while driving. Moreover, unlike men, women who are less skilled at driving are still labeled with the derogatory term 'Mrs. Kim [a pejorative term for female drivers stereotyped as incompetent].'

○ Female Drivers Being Disrespected

The joint reporting team from Dong-A Ilbo and Channel A for the 'Start Your Engine, Good Driving' project asked 182 female drivers aged 20-60 nationwide various questions related to 'driving as a woman' over a week starting from the 20th. 60.4% of respondents (110 people) answered that they had felt disrespected by other drivers simply for being female drivers. During the survey process, complaints poured in such as "Even when an accident was caused by the male driver's fault, he lectured me saying 'don't drive like that'" and "I overtook a car that was going too slowly, but when he realized I was a woman, he made sure to overtake my car."

Respondents pointed to the prejudice that 'women can't drive' as the most difficult 'wall' to overcome. They said that even when driving at the regulated speed, there are still many cases of being honked at or threatened to speed up. Ms. Lee (67, female), who has been driving for nearly 30 years, said, "I've seen male drivers speeding or violating traffic signals while shouting 'you have to go with the flow' many times." Many female drivers also thought that other drivers disrespected them when cutting in without signaling or maintaining safe distances. Ms. Kim Eun-hee (42, female) said, "A male driver saw me and suddenly tried to cut in. When I didn't yield, he followed me to the next traffic light, rolled down his window, and cursed at me."

Prejudice that assumes women are more at fault than men in contact accidents also persisted. Ms. Yoon (51, female), who works as a driving school instructor, said, "Two years ago, my car was rear-ended while waiting at a traffic light, but the other driver said 'since you're a woman, you could have made a mistake' and blamed me. Not only the other party but even the insurance company employees only acknowledged it was the rear car's fault after seeing the dashcam footage." A female driver in her 20s complained, "A taxi forcefully cut in front of me and our side mirrors slightly collided, but he scolded me like I was a child and drove off."

○ "Yield One More Time" - Advice for Female Drivers

We asked veteran female drivers for advice for women facing difficulties on the road. Yoon Young-mi, vice president of the Korea Federation for Environmental Movement's Mothers' Safety Leadership Association, said, "You shouldn't be intimidated so that you can properly claim your rights when you face unfair situations from male drivers," adding "However, rather than just trying to fight, an attitude of yielding is also necessary." Han Su-jin, section chief at the Korea Transportation Safety Authority, advised, "Paying attention to defensive driving is the secret to 30 years without accidents."

Changing the prejudices of surrounding male drivers and urging them to practice considerate driving is also one method. Kang Soon-ip, manager of the Incheon Women Drivers Association, said, "I always tell my son not to look down on female drivers," adding "Please make sure to tell your family members who are closest to you that women and men are equal on the road."

Joint Planning:
Ministry of Public Safety and Security, Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport, National Police Agency, Korea Transportation Safety Authority, General Insurance Association of Korea, Korea Transport Institute, TBS Traffic Broadcasting

{
  "translated_title": "[My Opinion] How Long Will We Just Watch the 'Disruption of 12th Grade Classrooms' After CSAT?",
  "translated_text": "Jeon Sang-hun, Principal of Gwangju Cheomdan High School

I'm worried. While I'm concerned about the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] that's about a month away, what worries me more is what happens after CSAT. Some people say that while there's a lot schools should teach for students' holistic development, as long as college entrance is the realistic goal of high school education, we just need to help manage their school records well and ensure they perform well on CSAT—what's there to worry about after that? But when I think about the essence of education, the reason schools exist, and the future of our children, my heart becomes heavy with concern.

As someone responsible for managing a frontline high school, I feel ashamed to say this, as if I'm spitting in my own face. The educational disruption that occurs every year after CSAT—that is, the phenomenon where classrooms fall into a kind of 'educational vacuum' within an implicit cartel between teachers and students who think that since the test is over, teachers have nothing more to teach and students have nothing more to learn—clearly reveals the current state of our education system, which is buried solely in college entrance exams and lacks even basic reflection on what schools should truly teach and what kind of humans they should cultivate.

Once CSAT ends, empty seats in classrooms increase as students rush to hagwon districts in Seoul, Gyeonggi, and other metropolitan areas to participate in rolling admissions interviews conducted by individual universities or to prepare for essay-writing exams or practical skill tests for regular admissions. In the chaotic atmosphere of a marketplace with students coming and going, even if classes are held, they can only be formal, and studying cannot possibly enter students' minds. In such situations, keeping students within school boundaries is as difficult as holding onto an unbridled colt, and in some ways, even reckless.

Of course, most schools try to fill the gap with special education programs such as creative experiential activities, career education, essay guidance, practical skill guidance, reading guidance, special lectures by external instructors, and small-scale sports competitions, each establishing their own measures. However, there are no suitable educational programs or materials to keep 12th graders intoxicated with the liberation from entrance exam hell in the classroom. Students kill time watching videos, chatting, and sleeping, and even their patience quickly reaches its limit. The feelings of teachers who helplessly watch this can only be as empty and hopeless as scarecrows standing blankly in harvested fields.

In the stark reality where the second semester of 12th grade, which is not reflected in college entrance school record calculations, has become virtually meaningless, allowing this structural vicious cycle to continue—where the month and a half from when CSAT ends until winter vacation begins becomes a time of actual educational incapacity and educational abandonment—while calling for normalization of school education is like trying to catch fish by climbing a tree.

Educational authorities must prepare fundamental improvement measures for the current CSAT system that reveals these various problems. It would be worth reviewing delaying the CSAT timing to mid-December by about a month and appropriately adjusting the excessively skewed rolling admissions-oriented recruitment ratio. Please devise practical solutions to return high school education to normal.

Jeon Sang-hun, Principal of Gwangju Cheomdan High School"
}

○ Subject areas and difficulty level showed little difference from previous years

Starting with this year's second-half (July-December) open recruitment, Samsung only gave GSAT testing opportunities to applicants who passed the job suitability assessment. 'Do people really have to hold their smartphones with their hands for such a long time?'

Jung Jae-hyun, CEO of Myfob Co., Ltd. (31), suddenly had this thought while riding the subway in 2012. Passengers around him were all holding smartphones and watching videos without exception. It looked uncomfortable.

At the time, he had quit his job at a bank after graduating from university and was preparing for graduate school entrance exams for translation and interpretation. He too would play English lectures or American dramas on his smartphone for English study whenever he traveled, holding the device by hand while watching. He thought that since you don't need to press buttons while watching videos, there's really no need to hold the smartphone by hand. An idea suddenly came to him. 'If there were a necklace-type smartphone stand, you wouldn't need to use your hands...'

But when he searched the internet, there was no such device. Although he didn't know much about entrepreneurship, he went to the Korean Intellectual Property Office with just his idea. After consulting with a patent attorney, he filed for a utility model the following year. While simultaneously preparing for entrance exams and developing the product, he thought: 'Now is the time to create this product!'

○ Nurturing dreams at the entrepreneurship academy

CEO Jung gave up on graduate school and entered the 'Youth Entrepreneurship Academy' operated by the Small and Medium Business Corporation last year. This is a program that annually selects young entrepreneurs preparing for startups, provides systematic education, and supports subsidies of up to 100 million won [approximately $75,000 USD] for 70% of total project costs. When he worked at the company, he would wake up at 7 AM, go to work, and leave before 7 PM, but now he goes to work at all hours and sometimes works until 2 or 3 AM. CEO Jung said, 'When I lived a routine life, I was extremely bored, but now that I'm doing what I want to do, even though my body is tired, I feel great accomplishment.'

'Entrepreneurship is like playing a game. From conception to product launch, each stage is fun, like completing game missions and moving to the next level.'

○ Enduring difficulties with the ambition to grow a company

According to the 'Startup Company Status Survey' (based on 2012 data, companies within 7 years of startup) released this month by the Small and Medium Business Administration, people in their 20s (22,817) and 30s (243,275) account for 16% of the 1,661,481 entrepreneurs. Moreover, manufacturing startups are challenging for young people in their 20s because not only is it difficult to conceptualize ideas, but they also require significant capital and market development is not easy.

'My goal is for the company I'm growing to become wealthy rather than myself. I want to make products that people need, products that even our family can use with confidence and satisfaction.'

Korea University explained the significance of the reform as "contributing to the normalization of public education and discovering future-oriented talent." To put this more simply, it means "we will broaden opportunities not just for students from specific regions like Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] or special-purpose high schools and autonomous private high schools, but also for students from general high schools or provincial schools who face difficult circumstances." The idea is to discover the potential of students who are passionate and sincere even if their current circumstances are not favorable, and students who have difficulty receiving hagwon education, and give them admission opportunities. This is based on the belief that character and integrity lead to higher achievement in university than grades at high school graduation.

There are also criticisms of Korea University's reform plan. First, there is the criticism that it fails to properly reflect differences in academic ability between schools. Simply put, "general high schools perform worse academically than special-purpose high schools and autonomous private high schools, so why should they get the same number of recommendation slots?" There are also concerns that competition between general high schools and school records [GPA] competition will intensify, and hagwon education for interviews will increase.

However, from the perspective of our society's greater good and public interest, Korea University's admissions system reform deserves applause. While there may be various values and orientations in education, the core should be coexistence. Education is about teaching and learning how to live together. This means consideration for the disadvantaged.

Looking around us, there are many cases where people want to study hard and want to raise their children with care, but cannot do so because of poor conditions such as poverty. It has become an undeniable reality that parents' economic conditions and social status determine our children's university admission results and future. Coexistence is crumbling.

Some people worry about the proliferation of hagwon education for in-depth interviews, but universities can sufficiently solve this problem. It is not very difficult for interviewers to screen out students who learned interview techniques through hagwon education. It is possible with just the will to do so. If they screen out students who learned interview techniques by relying on hagwon education, word will spread immediately, and test-takers and parents will naturally realize that interview hagwon education is unnecessary.

Korea University's admissions system reform plan was possible because of faith in students and the educational field. It is the belief that students with good character who work hard earnestly will pursue bigger dreams and contribute to our society, even if their circumstances and environment are poor. Prior to this, Korea University had also announced a policy to concentrate scholarships on students from difficult family circumstances rather than academically excellent students. All of this comes from consideration and coexistence.

Our society has deliberately turned away from this basic educational philosophy. In the name of competitiveness and excellence. That is why Korea University's attempt this time cannot but be a courageous experiment. Now is the time for our society and universities to respond to that courage."

{
  "translated_title": "[Dong-A Plaza/Park Hyeong-ju] The Productivity of Curiosity",
  "translated_text": "**Nobel Prize winners who aren't geniuses**
**German physicist who set no goals, led by joy of discovery to achievement**
**Japanese mathematician immersed in Buddhism also solved mathematical problems through joyful research**
**Repetitive learning that kills curiosity unavoidable in college entrance exam education**
**Don't give up saying it's too late, but draw the big picture**

Park Hyeong-ju, Director of National Institute for Mathematical Sciences, Ajou University Distinguished Professor

Human history overflows with supermen who achieved great feats through innate genius, but aren't there also figures among those far from genius who rose to the ranks of great scientists? The rebellion of ordinary people must occasionally occur for the world to be interesting.

Of course there are. The secret they speak of can be summarized as something like 'the productivity of curiosity.' This is completely different from the 'importance of repetitive learning' that our country's college entrance exam education treats as golden rules, and even seems contradictory to it. It's also quite different from the conventional advice to set clear goals during school years and devote oneself to them.

German physicist Professor Theodor Hänsch, during his 2005 Nobel Prize in Physics acceptance lecture, displayed on screen a picture that seemed to have little relation to profound physics theory. The picture showed a mother hen and chick, with appetizing feed on the right side and the hungry mother hen struggling to get close to it. However, an obstacle made of woven wood was spread before it, making her efforts pitifully futile. Meanwhile, a chick curious about what was on the opposite side of the feed left its mother and set out to explore the other direction. Wandering here and there in the wide open space, it eventually passed by the obstacle and reached the feed. Above the mother hen was written 'goal-oriented research,' and above the chick was written 'curiosity-driven research.'

Hänsch describes himself as an ordinary student with no connection to genius. He expressed in this picture the story of how such a person came to receive the Nobel Prize and rise to the ranks of great physicists. One can even read the provocative message 'throw away goals.' There's a kind of exhilaration in 'I lived led by the joy of new discoveries without any thought of achieving something (purpose), and found myself before appetizing feed (Nobel Prize).'

Professor Hironaka Heisuke, who won the Fields Medal—the highest award in mathematics—as the second person from Asia, also says he was an ordinary talent far from genius. His autobiography 'The Joy of Learning' shows a child who was at best a clever semi-talent growing into one of the world's greatest mathematicians. His Fields Medal-winning achievement, the abstruse research on 'resolution of singularities of algebraic varieties,' is also far from a genius of the century appearing suddenly to solve an age-old problem. Hironaka had been immersed in the Buddhist perspective that the complete world of nirvana becomes the phenomenal world full of suffering when projected into this world. The autobiography's title fits well with the message that 'joy creates achievement,' depicting the process by which philosophical contemplation led to solving mathematical problems.

What stands at the opposite pole from the perspective of curiosity's productivity is repetitive learning, which, contrary to its purpose of making things familiar through repetition, makes talented children sick of it and stop at mediocre achievement. The more the same content is repeated, the more rapidly interest drops and the child's curiosity disappears somewhere. There's even pride competition over how many times famous problem books have been solved. Teachers in the field know the problems but have no choice but to avoid repetitive learning, which is their magic bullet. The college entrance exam-centered education system has created an evaluation system that requires solving many multiple-choice problems in a short time, making the structure inevitably become 'beginning-development-climax-repetitive learning.'

Schools selectively teach parts of humanity's achievements. Among these, there are things like multiplication tables that, once memorized, can be used repeatedly to save effort. There are also things where, after learning, one can retain the basic principles or logical process of solution but may forget the detailed content. It's sufficient if one can look them up on the internet or in books when needed, or reproduce them through logical thinking processes. This is different from being good at computers and searching well—what's important is understanding what to look for to solve one's problems while having the big picture of knowledge interconnections.

Recently I saw news that a 73-year-old retired lawyer received a physics PhD in the United States and started as a postdoctoral researcher. Having served as Seoul District Court Chief Judge, he's someone who achieved mastery in his lifelong field, but at age 66 after mandatory retirement, he entered graduate school and began studying physics. He said he wanted to fulfill his childhood dream that had to be abandoned for various worldly reasons, even if it was after retirement. The joy and curiosity of learning new things appear in various forms.

Park Hyeong-ju, Director of National Institute for Mathematical Sciences, Ajou University Distinguished Professor"
}

"Which section of student records should reading activities be written in?"
This is a question students ask during information sessions or counseling. Of course, it goes in the reading activity section, but it's important to remember that student record sections are not disconnected from each other—they are organically connected to comprehensively reveal that student.
Reading activities can be recorded in the career aspiration rationale section as books that provided the catalyst for choosing that career path. The same goes for the creative experiential activities section. Students can choose books as subject matter for club activities to explore, or reading may have been a major catalyst or turning point for specific volunteer activities. If reading influenced career setting and maturity, it can also be recorded in the career activities section. In the subject-specific abilities and special notes section, it's good to record impressions after reading books related to 'subject classes.'
The reading activity section should detail what was learned and felt through such reading. Record which parts of the book resonated, what new information was gained, and how it changed one's thoughts and actions. For books to be read in the future, it's a good method to classify and record them as subject-related books, major-related books, liberal arts books, etc. Particularly, since the reading activity section records reading activities by subject, if English is divided into English 1 and English Reading in one semester, different reading activities can be recorded for each.

○ Career Activities, School Competition Participation... Work Hard Even in Senior Year
"There are many school events before final exams—what should I do first?"
This is a time when many events like festivals, trips, school competitions, and performance assessments [school-based assessment] take place at each school. To write a comprehensive student record admission personal statement, you need to recall in detail what you experienced during specific activities. When interviewing people from various professions, I often discover we share the common trait of being parents of middle and high school students. Even when we clash and get red-faced over differing opinions, we find ourselves on the same side before this common denominator, wielding our whips toward education authorities and schools while echoing each other's grievances. After pouring out the unfair experiences and damages our own children have suffered, we present swift solutions like cutting through a tangled mess.

Usually, there are two types. Solutions to simultaneously resolve the excessive but completely unchanging hagwon education problem and the university admissions system that's harder to decipher than a random number table. It's simple. For hagwon education, they say don't think too hard about it—just prohibit it by law. Those in their 40s and 50s who experienced the tutoring ban during the Chun Doo-hwan regime raise their voices saying, "What can't be done? Just do it." They say the complex admissions system is also a matter that can be simply resolved by letting students enter universities based solely on CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] scores. It feels like beating evil with the club of justice, but I wonder whether this would truly make the children of this land happy. Even during the iron-fisted Chun Doo-hwan regime, tutoring didn't completely disappear. If universities admitted students based solely on CSAT scores, it's obvious that the hagwon education market would catch fire even more. It's hard to empathize with the idea of abolishing diverse early admission programs that nurture each student's strengths to prevent them from becoming 'slaves to scores,' and returning to the admissions system of 20-30 years ago that made students focus solely on entrance exam preparation.

The answer to such problems is 'normalization of public education.' Schools just need to teach well—whether it's academics or arts and physical education—so that hagwon education becomes unnecessary. The admissions system may be complex, but is it really that difficult for homeroom teachers to find suitable programs for each individual student in their class?

Many student parents are curious about how many points teachers would score if they took the CSAT in the same year as their students. When asked, teachers either get annoyed first, or face endless criticism about school classes being at an incomparably low level compared to internet lectures, but there are no politicians or ministers who want to fix this aspect.

If we demanded that incompetent teachers be eliminated and that teachers work harder so all education takes place within schools, there would obviously be organized backlash centered on teachers' organizations. With the kind of boldness that would close down various hagwons operating normally, we could reasonably make the same demands of teachers, yet Gyeonggi Governor Nam Kyung-pil is only beating up on hagwons. All that's needed is to firmly establish a teacher evaluation framework and make the ordinary common sense of school teachers—not hagwon instructors—teaching children become the norm.

While talking about the era of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, can we call it education when we still demand familiarity with memorization-focused, rapid arithmetic operations instead of fostering creativity? Given this reality, various presidential candidates are competing to raise their voices about abolishing education policies or authorities. Looking at authorities that can't properly manage shoddy admissions or even respond adequately to history textbook issues, this seems understandable at first glance. However, education isn't something where new flesh suddenly sprouts if you cut it off with a single stroke.

The tangled threads of half-hearted reforms must be unraveled one by one to find their proper form. The more skilled a renowned doctor is at complex and difficult surgeries, the more they persistently stick to the task—taking time and effort rather than making one big cut—precisely excising only the cancerous mass to reduce side effects and save the patient. This is why we must support and vote for candidates who, rather than simply advocating easy abolition, will take the difficult path of meticulously repairing broken public education. I hope that from now on, various presidential candidates will set aside grandiose 'abolition pledges' and embark on the 'path of educational repair,' even if it takes some effort."

  "translated_text": "[Saturday Interview] Yonsei University President Kim Yong-hak Marks First Anniversary of Inauguration

Yonsei University President Kim Yong-hak, marking his first anniversary in office, met with a Dong-A Ilbo reporter on the 15th at Yonsei University's main building in Seodaemun-gu, Seoul, to discuss his reflections from leading the school for a year and his future vision. Photo by Kim Kyung-je, kjk5873@donga.com

Yonsei University President Kim Yong-hak (64, sociology professor), marking his first anniversary in office, mentioned the word "startup" more than twenty times during a 90-minute interview with Dong-A Ilbo on the 15th. His deep concerns were evident about how even graduates of the prestigious private university Yonsei face the reality that the "employment cliff" is not just someone else's problem. President Kim emphasized, "Universities will no longer be knowledge transmitters but will play a role in discovering and managing individual capabilities," adding, "Prestigious universities must abandon the privileges they once enjoyed and open various paths of challenge to students." We heard about the achievements and reflections since he became head of his alma mater on February 1 last year, as well as his future vision.

○ Toward a Noisy Library Stocked with 'Human Books'

President Kim said a 'noisy library' is needed to create a university culture that encourages startups. He meant that libraries should not be solitary spaces focused on books, but should become breeding grounds for startup networks where students can meet mentors who can vividly share their experiences.

President Kim said, "The era of studying alone while concentrating on books is over. Just as one visits the library to find books when academically curious, I will transform it into a library where students can meet startup mentors—what we might call 'human books'—when they want to start businesses but have questions." To this end, he plans to remodel the first-floor rest area of the Academic Information Center (library) on Sinchon campus into a startup mentoring space, opening in May. The policy is to enable students dreaming of startups to meet current industry professionals and entrepreneurial seniors there.

For university students, startups mean venture companies. President Kim emphasized that for many successful venture companies to emerge, "universities must transform into tropical rainforest-like environments." He meant that while universities have been agricultural societies that harvest one fruit (result) from one seed (research), future universities should become tropical rainforests where all possible types of seeds are sown and various challenges bear fruit.

"Just as you don't know what seeds will fall and what fruits will grow in a tropical rainforest, the goal is to create an environment where ideas can grow naturally. My greatest wish would be to see a venture company established by Yonsei students with annual sales of 2 trillion won [approximately $1.5 billion USD]."

Yonsei University has been running various programs supporting startups for undergraduate and graduate students since last year. One such program provides activity funding for two months when first-year students form small-scale project research teams. For graduate students, the university collected convergent research ideas that break down academic boundaries between humanities, engineering, and medical schools, providing research funding to 23 teams.

○ "Creativity Comes from Networks"

Befitting a master of social network theory, President Kim emphasizes teaching methods that value connectivity with others to draw out creativity. This aligns with his argument against studying alone with just books. The underlying idea is that startups can be achieved more easily through social networks.

Last semester, 95 classes were held where students studied course content in advance and solved problems through discussion only in the classroom. President Kim said, "For example, if a class discusses 'fake news,' students must study what recent incidents occurred, what theoretical approaches are relevant, and how to eradicate it in order to participate in class."

Since last year, he has been actively encouraging not only students but also professors to utilize MOOC (Massive Open Online Course) platforms that connect with universities worldwide. President Kim emphasized, "A 'Smartphone Application Programming' course uploaded by a Yonsei professor ranked in the top 10 popular MOOC lectures worldwide," adding, "Professors think about lectures that students worldwide might be interested in, and students can watch lectures uploaded by scholars from around the world."

'Star' professors from both universities will jointly open courses where Korea University and Yonsei students attend classes in the same space. ○ Management Philosophy Embodying the 3C Spirit

All of President Kim's plans stem from a management philosophy called '3C.' The 3C stands for the first letters of Christianity, Creativity, and Connectivity. Putting Christianity first is intended to emulate the founding spirit of missionary Horace Grant Underwood, Yonsei University's founder. President Kim explained, "Just as Severance Medical School [predecessor of Yonsei's medical school] produced the first Western-style doctor from a butcher's son at the end of the Joseon period, social contribution should come first."

Yonsei University will launch the Global Social Contribution Institute on April 10, the school's founding anniversary, becoming the first domestic university to have an organization overseeing the school's social contribution activities. It will integrate domestic and international social contribution activities of medical centers, welfare centers, and youth cultural centers with annual budgets exceeding 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD]. President Kim said, "While it's important for students to differentiate themselves through knowledge and creativity, the foundation is character," adding, "Please watch Yonsei University maintain its role as an educational institution that nurtures global talent with ethical consciousness and sustains Korean society.""

Mr. Kim, a math school teacher at a regular high school in Seoul, takes a deep breath every time he enters the classroom. He said, "About a third of each class sleeps, but that's still better since it's a science track class," sighing as he added, "Liberal arts classes are much more serious. More than half are kids who already gave up on math from middle school." Teacher Gu said, "Since I can't provide customized lessons anyway, I just let them sleep. That's the best I can do."

○ School Classes Running on Empty, Students Go to Hagwons to Survive

Mathematics isn't just painful for teachers teaching to thin air and children who have to 'kill time.' Even students who are good at math complain that "math is boring" and "I don't know why I have to do this."

Student Song, who got only one question wrong in last year's CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) math section, which was evaluated as an 'extremely difficult CSAT,' is considered a math prodigy in Seoul's Mok-dong, known for its high educational fervor. In last year's CSAT, he solved 28 out of 30 math problems in 30 minutes when given 100 minutes. However, Song said, "The reason I got high scores wasn't because I had good understanding of principles or application skills, but because I practiced identifying problem types and fast calculation countless times," adding "To get high scores, you need to immediately recognize what type of formula to use the moment you see a problem."

The characteristic of Korean-style math assessment is that you must solve 'many problems quickly within a short time.' Only getting the answer matters, and mostly the solution process isn't graded nor are partial points recognized. In school exams, one or two high-difficulty problems that go beyond the curriculum or require advance learning always appear. This is because students must be 'ranked.'

○ Economic Gaps Become Hagwon and Academic Achievement Gaps

What's needed to avoid becoming a 'math dropout' (one who gave up on mathematics) is 'tricks' and 'type identification,' but schools don't teach these methods. This is why students have no choice but to go to hagwons to get high scores.

Currently, mathematics is the subject with the largest share in Korea's middle and high school hagwon education market. According to a 2015 Statistics Korea survey released last year, 42.5% of domestic households provide math hagwon education to their children. Hagwon education participation rates are proportional to household economic income. When household average monthly income was less than 1 million won [approximately $750 USD], math hagwon education participation was 13.2%, but as income increased by 1 million won [approximately $750 USD] increments, math hagwon education participation rates continued to increase to 23.4%, 33.8%, 42.0%, 48.0%, 51.5%, and 54.4%. When monthly income was 7 million won [approximately $5,250 USD] or more, the participation rate was 56.4%, 4.3 times higher than households with monthly income under 1 million won [approximately $750 USD].

Student Jung, who is about to enter elementary school this year, attends three math hagwons per week alone. These include a thinking skills math hagwon that supposedly develops 'thinking power,' a calculation hagwon that trains calculation tricks, and a hagwon that helps with advance learning for curriculum preparation including word problems. Parent Ms. Lee said, "Three math sessions per week is average level in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry]," adding "Especially calculation math is essential from kindergarten. Even though the child dislikes it, the effects are so good we can't quit."

Another Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] area parent, Ms. Kim, said, "Recently science and engineering fields are trending, and since English became absolute evaluation in this year's CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], mothers' interest in math hagwon education has increased even more," conveying that "If the past ratio of English to math hagwons was 3 to 2, now the trend is to reduce one English class and add one more math class."

High school teacher Mr. Kim said, "From what I see in the field, economic gaps and whether students attend hagwon education are directly connected to math assessment results," adding "Sometimes I see middle-tier kids with outstanding mathematical thinking ability, but realistically on tests, these kids can't surpass the scores of children who've done 2-3 years of advance learning."

Success or failure in college entrance exams also depends on hagwons. Mr. Lee, who attends a prestigious engineering college in Seoul and graduated from a regular high school in Guri, Gyeonggi Province, said, "My life's math teacher is online instructor Mr. S," asserting "If it weren't for Mr. S, I absolutely couldn't have gone to college." He said, "I'm not disrespecting school teachers, but listening only to school classes, you absolutely cannot get high scores whether on the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] or school tests," adding with a bitter smile, "If you told school teachers to take the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], there wouldn't be anyone who could get a perfect score."

○ "Current Math Education Is Neither Math nor Education"

While school classes aim for principles and basic concepts, assessments pursue application and high difficulty. In this contradiction, children who can't afford hagwons or can't adapt to speed-focused problem-solving assessments end up giving up on mathematics entirely.

Professor Lee Yong-hoon of Busan University's Department of Mathematics said, "Korea's math assessment focuses on calculation and speed, but strictly speaking, this isn't mathematics," shaking his head as he added, "Even though both my wife and I are math professors, our child gave up on math when they entered high school."

Professor Kim Jung-han of the Korea Institute for Advanced Study's Department of Computational Sciences analyzed, "Mathematics becomes a subject with too much to memorize once it starts becoming a memorization subject," adding "Mathematics becomes the most difficult subject when rote learning education and assessment that involves memorizing problem types and formulas takes place, which is why math dropouts emerge first among all subjects.""

Principal Kim Dong-chun (53) of Daejeon Imun High School, a private school, was just about a month ago a regular teacher teaching history at Daeseong Girls' Middle School. Imun High School, which fell into crisis due to declining student numbers, brought him in as a relief pitcher unrelated to the foundation. This unprecedented external recruitment is the first in the private school sector in the Daejeon region. There is high interest inside and outside the education community as to whether this will become a catalyst for other private middle and high schools experiencing similar crises due to declining school-age population to bring in external personnel.
○ Daejeon's first unprecedented appointment of regular teacher as principal
Imun Academy, which started as Haedong Academy in 1964, operates two schools under its umbrella: Imun High School and Sintanjin Middle School. It is well known that the late Lee Byeong-mu, who accumulated money through an ironware store at Daejeon Central Market, established the school to fulfill his regret of not having received an education.
However, recently student numbers have drastically decreased, creating a sense of crisis. In the case of Imun High School, student numbers dropped from 210 in 2014 to 164 this year, and the declining trend is expected to become even steeper in the future.
Since the school is located in Sintanjin on the outskirts of Daejeon, the decline in school-age population has been pronounced, and although it was belatedly incorporated into the equalization zone, it lacks competitiveness as there are no applications from the city center. Changes and innovation in the teaching community are also difficult to expect. This is due to the characteristics of private schools where teachers work in one place for 20-30 years without exchanges.
Early this year, Board Chairman Lee Jae-kwang (53, photo) decided to find a solution through external recruitment of a principal. Having worked in the financial industry for over 30 years while operating the school and currently serving as an executive managing director at SK Securities, he determined that 'thinking outside the box' was necessary. Chairman Lee said, "While schools aim for human education, the methods must be innovative like the service industry. To create 'a school students want to attend, parents want to send their children to, and teachers want to work at,' external recruitment was necessary."
For private schools to exclude relatives from appointments to key school positions requires quite a significant decision. Around 2009, when student numbers had drastically declined, Chairman Lee said "To change the school, the foundation must first give up authority and benefits," and hired an administrative director through public recruitment. The publicly recruited administrative director, who came from a business background, breathed vitality into the school through cafeteria and auditorium expansion and construction.
○ Interest in whether external recruitment will continue at private middle and high schools
Chairman Lee held a school management planning meeting to explain the school's crisis and emphasize the necessity of external recruitment. This is because many school teachers dream of becoming principals through internal promotion. He then searched extensively to find three candidates and decided to recruit Principal Kim through board resolution. While external recruitment of principals at private schools is stipulated by law and there are precedents in other cities and provinces, this is the first time in Daejeon.
Chairman Lee said, "Although Principal Kim is a nationally known college entrance exam specialist, we expected him to fundamentally change the school because he equally possesses innovative and balanced work handling and educational philosophy." Principal Kim has served as co-representative of the National Academic Guidance Council, advisory committee member of Seoul National University's High School-University Liaison Council, and lead instructor for EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] college admission information sessions.

Science labs and libraries are kept open at all times, and evening study sessions have diversified beyond subject study to include discussion classes and arts and physical education activities. Students create and participate in clubs they want rather than those predetermined by the school.
Principal Kim said, "Through my long experience with entrance exams, I learned that restoring the curriculum to normal through a balance of curricular and extracurricular activities is the best method not only for human education but also for improving college admission results," and expressed his ambition: "I want to leave a good precedent as a recruited principal by pursuing the essential purpose of education without being conscious of college admission.""

  "translated_text": "Lee Dong-young, Deputy Chief of Policy and Society Department

As a major election season opens, hagwon education is once again under fire. There's no need for lengthy detailed explanations. It's because people perceive it as roughly the root of evil that causes exam fever and destroys public education. When you see news about parents' backs breaking under the money they pour into hagwons and children having to grab meals at convenience stores late at night, this country's hagwon education problem seems like a mutant zombie virus impervious to any prescription.

With this kind of national anger, campaign promises emerge to abolish hagwon education through a national referendum, and news reports continue in the vein of 'this is why hagwon education is problematic' without presenting concrete alternatives. Looking at the campaign promises of several presidential candidates and articles harshly criticizing hagwon education, one might think the hagwon education market will collapse within days. I asked an executive from a hagwon education company for their opinion.

'That's just talk - nothing will change, so there's no need to protest. If the goal is to normalize public education, schools should just teach well. But why do they only bash hagwon education as the problem?'

While this is certainly logic armed with self-interest, I think we need to consider why the path to public education normalization is sought through bashing hagwon education. If you grabbed parents and asked 'Between schools and hagwons, which takes responsibility for your children's studies?', what results would emerge? Ignoring this reality and focusing solely on bashing hagwon education - can good prescriptions come from this approach? Instead of thinking about restraining hagwons from advance learning, why don't we devise and apply excellent learning methods so that students who properly go through the process of sequential, step-by-step learning and mastery receive high evaluations?

Hagwon instructors must teach well to be chosen by students and parents. Otherwise, they're kicked out after classes are cancelled overnight. So they teach in ways that are easy for students to understand, pinpointing exactly what's needed. Though they go through ruthless evaluation, they're given the clear carrot of hefty compensation, so hagwons truly operate efficiently.

What about schools? Try to select teachers who teach well, and they're likely to collectively rebel, saying it 'brings the bloody winds of competition to public education.' I've even seen a teacher who responded with head-shaving to a high school principal's proposal to move up arrival and dismissal times by 20 minutes each to spend the day more efficiently. The atmosphere is such that excellent students apply to education universities, pass the teacher employment exam after fierce competition, gain the glorious title of educator, and then don't need to make any effort whatsoever. If schools taught better than hagwons and, based on that confidence, gave students appropriate amounts of homework to complete individually or in groups, there would be nowhere to go even if you pushed them toward hagwons.

Can public education be revived by ignoring the most urgent need to improve teacher quality and only hammering hagwons? As long as such misguided prescriptions continue, there's no way to prevent the qualitative decline of school education, and the screams of parents and students in the thriving hagwon education market will never cease. Hagwon education that uses shallow commercial tactics to stoke overheating by deceiving people that they must learn 10 books when learning just one would suffice, or hagwon education that instills fear in parents to make them fall into habitual addiction, must definitely be excised. These problems with hagwons can be precisely excised by applying the appropriate scalpel. That would be good, but closing hagwons doesn't automatically make schools better.

Are teachers beings who shouldn't compete? Without introducing measures to evaluate what efforts they've made to teach children well and dismiss those who fall short of standards, there is no future for this country's public education. It's time to stop the prescription of avoiding the clear infected area out of fear of backlash and applying the scalpel to the wrong places."

  "translated_text": "[Easy College Admissions If You Know in Advance] <13> Deciding on a Career Path as a High School Freshman

Q. I'm a parent with a high school freshman child. I'm worried because my child hasn't decided on a career path yet. How should I help them find their career direction?

A. The importance of career choice is growing, but it's not an easy task. It requires a process of looking inward at oneself. Others cannot teach you what you should do. They can provide information, but the choice belongs to the student.

There are two main reasons why students feel difficulty in choosing a career path. One is not knowing what they want to do, and the other is not knowing well what kinds of jobs exist.

If the reason is the latter, the solution is simple. Information about careers and academic majors can be easily obtained through internet searches or books. You can check what jobs exist in fields that interest you, what majors you need to study, what the work environment is like, and what the future prospects are.

However, if the reason for not being able to make a career choice is the former, it cannot be resolved simply. If your child says things like 'I don't have anything I want to do' or 'This is no good for this reason, that's no good for that reason,' then this applies to them.

In this case, students must explore their areas of interest themselves. They should refer to aptitude tests conducted at school and actively reflect on themselves. Think about what fields you look at with interest in newspapers, on the internet, or in bookstores. Also, if you answer questions yourself about which subjects or units you like in school classes, what you enjoy among hagwon or after-school activities, what was fun among school events, and whether there are fields you find yourself talking a lot about to others without realizing it, you will be able to see your areas of interest to some extent.

Once you've found your areas of interest to some degree, now you need to think about what you're good at. The era of simply saying you're good at studying or arts and physical education is over. Since everyone has different dispositions, everyone has their own strengths, and the key is whether you discover them or not.

Parents' observational skills from watching their children regularly are also a great help. Look back and see if you've ever talked to others about your child, saying things like 'My child speaks well and has a talent for persuading others,' 'They're good at assembling and making things,' or 'They're good at counseling friends' problems.' If not, even now, observe your child closely and think about your child's potential.

The career path in the first year of high school doesn't need to be an accurate choice down to a specific major or job. It's okay if it's comprehensive. It's enough if it can serve as a criterion for judgment at important moments of choice that must be made after entering high school, such as academic tracks and clubs. It's also good to steadily explore careers in areas of interest while spending your high school years and gradually make them more concrete with what suits you.

There is no correct answer in career choice. What's important is that it should be a career choice that comes from serious consideration about yourself, not an impulsive decision. For this, we must not forget that above all, a process of getting to know yourself through various experiences is necessary.

Jinhak-sa Youth Education Research Institute"

Korea's industrial development process differs from Western advanced countries. Korea skipped Process A and started directly from Process B, imitating advanced country products determined by the state or corporations. What was needed was technology for imitation. There was no need to understand the context of product and technology creation. This was the 'fast follower' strategy of succeeding by making things quickly and cheaply to sell. Korea's major industries—semiconductors, automobiles, shipbuilding, and steel—all went through this process.

  "translated_title": "[Donga Plaza/Hong Chan-sik Column] Why We Are Indifferent to History",
  "translated_text": "I once had the opportunity to attend a Baekje history lecture while visiting Japan. It was an event where a Baekje specialist from Korea was invited to share the latest research findings. Since it was hosted by a university, I assumed the audience would consist of young university students and graduate students. When I actually went to the lecture hall, I was surprised not only by the unexpectedly large audience of over 100 people, but also by the diverse demographics of men and women of all ages. Listening to the questions posed to the speaker at the end of the lecture, I learned that the occupations were varied—self-employed business owners, housewives, office workers, and others. What struck me most was their high level of curiosity about another country's history.

President Roh Moo-hyun reportedly ordered his cabinet members to study history, saying "the situation we face is similar to that of 100 years ago." Amid the controversy over historical distortion, voices calling for strengthened national history education are growing louder. The word 'history' will likely appear regularly in various current issues going forward, including the settlement of past affairs and conflicts between conservatives and progressives.

▼Can extending national history class hours solve the problem?▼

We tend to be indifferent to history. While it would be normal for historical knowledge to improve as one progresses from high school students to university students to the general public, there are survey results showing that historical knowledge actually decreases as one moves up these levels. Even if discourse about history overflows, if the majority of citizens don't know history, we cannot obtain the right answers from history. History can potentially transform into a weapon that divides society and harms others.

The question is where the reason for not knowing history lies. There are indeed problems with history education. However, designating national history as a mandatory subject on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) to make students study more history will not solve the problem.

When news broke that national history education would be strengthened, many negative opinions appeared on the internet. These were mainly reactions from teenagers who would face increased academic burden. Comments like 'Even if we designate national history as a mandatory subject, it will end up as rote memorization anyway, so what improvement is there over the current situation?' and 'The current two hours per week of classes aren't too few. Making the classes more interesting is more important.' Though these seem like spontaneous opinions, they contain the right answer.

National history has long been a representative memorization subject. There are countless miscellaneous things to memorize. After taking the test and turning away, that's the end of it. Expanding such classes would only increase resistance. There are many worrying aspects as well. The leftist bias in modern and contemporary history textbooks is serious. 'Strengthening national history education' could lead to 'strengthening ideological education.' It shouldn't become a platform for school teachers to preach their own historical views either.

Along with national history, one must also know world history to avoid falling into the trap of exclusive nationalism. To counter historical distortion with logic, one must know Chinese and Japanese history. Most essential is cultivating the thinking ability to judge history.

Originally, there are few fields as fascinating as history. All stories are based on history in some way, and history programs on TV are popular in every country. It's absurd how indifference to history has expanded and we've become unaware that others are stealing our history.

It cannot be said to be only the fault of history teachers. Entrance exam education focused on scores has blocked interest in history. Like the climate that neglects the humanities, society as a whole has failed to make history an object of curiosity. For instance, one role of public broadcasting is to produce easy-to-understand and interesting history programs that foster public interest in history. KBS's 'History Special,' which was quite popular, was quietly replaced by a 'Code' program. This is always how public broadcasting operates.

▼To become immersed in history▼

If there's any gain from the historical distortion controversy, it's that we've realized that interest in history is directly connected to our lives. When will the day come when we too become a 'curiosity paradise' for history, where audiences flock to history lectures?"
}

He urged, "Even if you receive disappointing results, never be discouraged or frustrated. Let's use this as a precious opportunity for a new beginning." I'm not sure how much comfort this provided to students who had already bombed the test after everything was over.

Watching this awkward and bitter scene of apology and consolation, I thought there was something else the education authorities should really apologize for. While such harsh realities of college entrance exams exist at the end of school life, they had misled young students into thinking they could live happily by just pursuing dreams and talents without really studying. Even aside from college admissions, due to the nature of human society, there inevitably must be evaluation and competition at every gateway like employment. However, it's true that education authorities had obscured schools' educational responsibilities by chanting 'happy education' to achieve their primary goal of 'reducing hagwon education [Korea's private tutoring industry]'.

Students' school life these days is vastly different from that of older generations. The biggest difference is that there are no 'unified exams' (tests taken by all grades together) like midterms or finals from first grade elementary through first grade middle school. However, elementary schools do conduct something called 'unit assessments' by class at the homeroom teacher's discretion to gauge children's understanding. These are often given without advance notice to prevent children from studying separately and experiencing excessive stress.

Some progressive-leaning education superintendents operate 'homework-free schools' as key projects, not just eliminating tests. Overseas, they promoted 'homework-free schools' by emphasizing 'learning within school,' such as extending class periods from 45 to 65 minutes. But our approach is simply 'let's not stress elementary lower grades.' In situations where guidelines are effectively issued at the education office level, teachers only exhaust themselves by assigning homework and don't get any praise for it.

Still, this much is okay. The problem starts from second grade middle school. After living a test-free life in first grade middle school under the names 'free semester system' and 'free year system,' children fall into shock when they take their first real 'exam' in second grade middle school. Even when they try to study belatedly, it's quite difficult since seven years have passed when they should have grasped basic concepts. Children who can only rely on school due to their circumstances have an even harder time. Those who cannot narrow this gap eventually remain as a group labeled 'below basic academic achievement.'

In an education system that encourages 'schools to teach less,' parents send their children to hagwon education with the mindset of 'if school won't make them do it, I will.' Mothers sometimes stick close to teach like teachers, even fighting with their children. Many 'do-as-I-say-not-as-I-do child education' figures we know also verbally advocate for happy education while actually having their own children walk the path of foreign language high schools, autonomous private high schools, gifted schools, and prestigious universities. If happy education is so good, why didn't they try it first with their own children?

Due to the nature of my work as a reporter, I get to observe various forms of education from education special districts' methods to marginalized communities' situations. People commonly use the expression 'tilted playing field' regarding Korea's education gap, but when you actually look, it's not just tilted—it's a 'broken playing field.' Those who have means don't care if schools teach less. They don't rely only on schools anyway. Only ordinary people who were too busy making a living to know what the college entrance system was like, who trusted only schools, get blindsided. In that sense, what education authorities should really apologize for is abandoning public education to idealism while turning a blind eye to reality. That comes before apologizing for 'CSAT Korean question 31.'"
}

When Jeong conveyed Kim's meaning, Kang Shin-won (24), who was calculating product costs, let out a small "Oh my..." sigh. Kim creates the products while Sungkyunkwan University students handle sales. Marketing and promotion are also the students' responsibility.

Kim fell into a coma from meningitis around the end of summer vacation in first grade of elementary school and woke up after three days. He saved his life but lost his hearing in return. His world as the neighborhood's ringleader changed overnight. Maintaining friendships and studying became overwhelming. "I didn't have any particular determination as a child. My parents said, 'Even if it's a bit difficult, it would be better to attend regular school,' so that's what I did."

In 2007, Kim began learning woodworking. At that time, the DIY (Do it yourself - consumers making desired items directly) trend had emerged. With support from the Korea Foundation for Persons with Disabilities, he learned woodworking twice a week for ten months at a workshop.   "translated_text": "Concerns about the 'revival of bon-gosa [comprehensive essay exams used before standardization]' seem to be spreading regarding Seoul National University's 2008 academic year college entrance examination plan. This can be seen as an intention to autonomously select students with excellent qualifications while respecting the education authorities' policy commitment to normalizing public education through standardization.

The problem is the essay-centered 'regular admission.' Of course, even in this case, the weight of school records (40%) and interviews (20%) remains high, but the practical determinant of acceptance or rejection appears likely to be decided by the essay exam (40%). Seoul National University announced that it would conduct a new type of essay examination, but if they cleverly conduct bon-gosa-style exams under the name of essay exams, serious side effects are expected. Even now, there are countless universities that conduct exams in bon-gosa format when you look inside, even though they're called essay exams in name only.

Seoul National University has also drawn a line saying it will avoid bon-gosa-style essay exams. Although specific research should follow, considering the position of frontline high schools and test-takers who are desperate for Seoul National University admission, there is a need to disclose question types as soon as possible to relieve anxiety.

And the current method of writing approximately 2,500-character answers over three hours with a single question has much room for improvement in that it is not significantly different from CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam), which evaluates several years of learning process in just one day. I would like to make several suggestions regarding the new type of essay examination that Seoul National University is envisioning.

First, essay questions must be dealt with within the scope of the high school curriculum. Students who are faithful to school studies without taking hagwon classes or private tutoring should be able to solve them sufficiently. Questions that require excessively abstract or high-level thinking abilities could rather become a pretext for the proliferation of hagwon education.

Second, changes in the number of questions and answer writing are required. In other words, while writing ability is also important, evaluating the degree of knowledge and application ability comes first. Therefore, it is necessary to adequately verify test-takers' intellectual level from various angles by requiring answers of not long length (around 700 characters per question) for at least five questions instead of a single question as currently done.

Third, it is necessary to conduct questions at the department or major level in addition to the current college and school-level question setting. Rather than evaluation centered on basic literacy as now, it is desirable to measure specific abilities related to majors. For example, we could consider having the English Literature department ask questions about English utilization ability, the Law department about basic abilities and qualifications as legal professionals, and the Business Administration department about economic common sense and business mindset.

Fourth, it should serve as an opportunity to evaluate broad reading ability. Since reading ability is difficult to depend on hagwon education, it is necessary to instill the recognition that reading various types of books is much more advantageous for college admission than students clinging to hagwons or private tutoring. If the importance of reading increases in Seoul National University essays, reading education at frontline high schools will also be activated.

Through these several principles, Seoul National University will be able to catch two rabbits simultaneously: universities' student selection rights and the normalization of public education. In that regard, I hope this admission plan can lead to an evaluation of 'meaningful progress in essay exams' rather than the 'revival of bon-gosa' that many people are concerned about.

The equalization system achieved considerable success in the 1970s and 80s. The state standardized schools, educational content, and evaluation, seeking to raise the overall quality of these elements. I believe equalization thus performed its role admirably in the industrial age, the era of small-variety mass production.

However, since the 1990s, our society has been rapidly changing from an industrial society to a global knowledge-based society. When the world changes, advantages can quickly turn into disadvantages. What about the equalization system?

Equalization is a system that standardizes everything. It is difficult to grasp the essence if we understand equalization merely as 'a method of randomly assigning schools by school district.' Equalization standardizes schools, curricula, educational content, educational methods, and also standardizes evaluation and college entrance exams [university admissions]. And if you just follow the standardized manual, no one takes responsibility. Therefore, it contrasts with liberal education that 'makes everyone act and move' and whose results are transparently revealed.

The equalization system is like a planned economy and collusion between politics and business in education. Education is a matter of concern for all citizens. And citizens' educational needs are diverse. There are many citizens who want equalization, and there are also many who oppose equalization and want modification. Therefore, what the government should do is guarantee diverse educational choice rights so that no class feels alienated from the nation and society.

Therefore, the more diverse schools are, the better. Also, the more specialized and professionalized education becomes, the better. From a functionalist perspective, education contributes to social stability and integration. Schools transmit the skills, knowledge, and community consciousness that society demands. It is said that school education can play a decisive role in national economic growth and development, as well as human self-realization, through skills training. It is also said that social contradictions can be resolved through school education and social equality can be achieved. Currently, high school equalization is being implemented in Seoul, the six major metropolitan cities, and 16 other cities. This was designed to allow people to change the social and economic status they received from their parents at birth according to their own abilities through educational equality. In other words, it can be seen as providing opportunities for class mobility through education.

○ In the Textbook... ② Conflict Theory

However, can these policy efforts realize the social integrative goal of alleviating social conflict through equalization of educational opportunities? Let's look at the following perspective.

"The reason social conflict exists is because resources that social members want to possess, such as economic wealth, political power, and social prestige, are scarce, and parts with different interests form conflicting relationships with each other, and as conflict intensifies, society changes. From a conflict theory perspective, social structure is a structure of dominance and subordination relationships based on unequal distribution of social resources, and therefore a structure that induces conflict between components." [High School Social Studies Textbook]

From a conflict theory perspective, education solidifies the existing social hierarchy and produces relationships of dominance and subordination. In other words, schools perpetuate social inequality by reproducing the existing order. The ideal of equity in educational opportunities is also merely formal. In reality, educational opportunities are inevitably given differentially according to parents' economic power, and this appears as differences in university admission rates. Viewed this way, education, which seems to be a bastion of equality in our society, actually plays a role in reproducing social inequality structures.

The following research results announced by Seoul National University's Institute for Social Sciences in 2005 support this fact (research subjects: Seoul National University College of Social Sciences admissions from 1970 to 2003):

"...The admission rate of children of fathers in high-income occupational groups (including executives of general companies) is 20 times higher than the admission rate of other groups, and recently this gap appears to be widening... [Seoul National University Institute for Social Sciences, 'Who Comes to Seoul National University']

○ Shouldn't We Focus Accurately?

What's important is that education should be able to realize substantial equality to solve problems. The reality where educational services are provided differentially according to income and region must be improved.

First, normalization of school education is necessary. This means that schools should provide educational services sufficient that students don't need help from hagwon education. Also, schools should develop various learning processes and evaluation methods to provide diverse educational services suited to individual students. Educational equality cannot be achieved by evaluating students with uniform standards. True educational equality is realized when students can compete in their preferred learning environment using the methods they are most confident in.

In the short term, various college admission systems should be established. To alleviate the realistic problem of academic disparities according to income and region, reasonable reverse discrimination measures for educationally marginalized classes are necessary. It is necessary to secure fairness in competition by expanding currently implemented systems such as regional balance admissions, school record-based admissions, and special admissions for people with disabilities.

Like other essay exams, the most important task in LEET [법학적성시험, Law School Admission Test] essay-writing is analyzing problems and provided texts.
