  "translated_text": "Self-study is more important than classes… maximize your spare time

Every December, I conduct college admissions consultations with students who have received their CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] score reports. At this time, harmonizing students' desires with their objective abilities is one of the most difficult challenges. Most test-takers want to receive higher scores than their current grades and enter universities where their chances of admission are high.

Since education is based on students' future potential, I don't blame these test-takers for this mindset. Students always study hard and expect grade improvement, but their grades don't rise as much as they think they will.

Why is this? This is the core concern of test-takers. Even this year, I want to tell test-takers who are studying hard until the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] to change their methods and study differently.

Most test-takers only study as much as others do. If everyone studies the same amount equally, it's not easy to improve grades.

If you want grade improvement, you need the mindset of always studying a little more than others. Use spare time or time you normally waste to solve even one more math problem than others.

The attitude of memorizing just 5 more English words than usual is important. The grade differences among test-takers are not originally large. You must remember that small differences always accumulate to create big differences. If you want to succeed, create small differences in your daily life.

More important for grade improvement is qualitative difference. The daily routines of 600,000 test-takers nationwide are almost similar. They do 'learning (學) = classes' and 'practicing (習) = self-study.' Since 'classes' involve interaction between teachers and students, individual student differences are not large. There can be qualitative differences in classes due to differences in teachers' abilities. Successful test-takers make good use of class time with an active attitude of participating enthusiastically in classes.

More important than classes is precisely 'self-study = self-directed learning.' Many students fall into the 'illusion' that they understand everything when listening to classes.

After classes, they must study on their own and actually make that content 'their own.' Since self-study is conducted individually, individual student differences occur. Self-study must be done more thoroughly.

Students who study successfully digest 15 hours' worth of learning when they study for 10 hours. On the other hand, students who fail only achieve 3-4 hours of actual learning even when studying for 10 hours. This qualitative difference in 'self-directed learning' varies according to concentration, study plans, study efficiency, etc.

Every admissions season, students who boast excellent grades unanimously say they 'got enough sleep' and 'were faithful to classes.' This means there was a qualitative difference in learning.

To improve concentration, goal consciousness is most important. In other words, students who accurately recognize why they study hard have high concentration. We need to think that studying is a process of intellectual growth that realizes future dreams.

People with weak concentration blame others, while people with strong concentration don't mind their surroundings. Concentration must be heightened to the extent that one is desperate.

If you flip through various books without a concrete plan when self-studying after classes end, you can consider it almost 100% failure. Without a study plan, tension cannot be maintained.

Students who have their own plans often feel regret when the dismissal bell rings. This happens when learning doesn't proceed according to plan. Day-by-day persistent cumulative learning ultimately connects to grade improvement.

It's necessary to keep in mind that study plans that complement one's weak points, as well as preparation and review for classes, are essential conditions for successful students and the shortcut to improving learning efficiency.

The absolute time given to test-takers is all the same. But relative time is different. Successful students maximize the time given to them.

Since students themselves are the protagonists of their lives, they must strive to become masters of their own time. Do you want to succeed? Don't be dominated by time, but become the dominator. Let's do our best for our precious future! Fighting!

Yu Jae-wook, Director of Cheongsol Hagwon [a hagwon/private academy], Incheon"

  "translated_title": "[Donga Plaza/Jung Jae-seung] The Physiology of Zero-Period Classes",
  "translated_text": "With the new government taking office, zero-period classes and evening self-study sessions (yaja time) have been deregulated. The state has declared it will no longer regulate zero periods and yaja time, which had been controlled at the national level due to concerns that excessive competition and college entrance exam supremacism could harm students' health and human rights. Now Korea's educational field has entered 'Darwin's ecosystem,' pervaded by the survival of the fittest and law of the jungle competition. Thanks to this, Korean students are developing collective sleep disorders. Students who already can't get even 7 hours of sleep, let alone the 9 hours appropriate for adolescents, will now face situations where they must wake up an hour earlier.

Parents who had to wage war every morning to wake their children will now have to fight this arduous battle even earlier, but in fact, this isn't because our kids are lazy—it's because they're healthy. Melatonin, which regulates human sleep cycles, typically begins secreting around 11 PM during puberty and remains in the system until after 9 AM. This tendency becomes stronger as puberty progresses and is more pronounced in high school than middle school.

Thus, teenagers sleeping late into the morning is a very natural phenomenon. If your child wakes up at 6 AM, exercises, then wakes up parents asking for breakfast while reading the newspaper, take them to a nearby hospital. They might have the body of a 60-year-old.

**Classes That Go Against Physiological Activity Have Reverse Effects**

Now that zero periods have begun and students must go to school at 7 AM, they'll be eating lunch boxes before second period and rushing to the school store after third period ends. The revival of zero-period classes is highly likely to disrupt Korean teenagers' biological rhythms and increase obesity and being overweight.

According to Dr. Mary Carskadon, a sleep scientist at Brown University, if teenagers appear listless, sensitive, or sullen, she recommends first examining whether they're getting sufficient sleep. Students who wake up before streetlights turn off cannot concentrate properly during class and are more likely to poorly regulate emotions like sadness or frustration. Irritable reactions also intensify, leading to increased classroom violence.

Schools probably created the 'mathematically very bizarre' concept of zero period to improve students' learning abilities, but paradoxically, what Korean teenagers need most for high academic achievement is morning sleep.

Research results support this, showing that students score higher when they sleep even 3 hours before taking an exam rather than taking it after pulling an all-nighter. While we sleep, our brain transfers important information learned before sleep to long-term memory while cleanly erasing useless information to recharge for receiving new information. It's like the process of erasing the blackboard while copying important content to notes in preparation for the next class.

So if your child is sleeping diligently, don't scold them to go wash their face, but find peace of mind by reciting this mantra: 'Right now our kid is diligently transferring what they learned yesterday to long-term memory. They're getting tutoring at the biological sleep hagwon.'

A few years ago, parents in various regions including Minneapolis, Minnesota and Katonah, north of New York City, persuaded school authorities based on sleep scientists' research results, saying 'Give our children the right to sleep in the morning.' Schools accepted this and delayed class times by 30 minutes, resulting in noticeably improved classroom atmosphere and higher SAT (Scholastic Assessment Test, a standardized college admission test in the US) scores. What Korean teenagers need most is sleep more than food, sleep more than hagwons.

**America Proves 'Sufficient Sleep = Academic Improvement'**

What's unfortunate is that most people deciding 'whether or not to have zero-period classes' are adults in their 50s and 60s whose melatonin secretion begins decreasing at 4 AM. They might feel very sorry that teenagers can't breathe the fresh dawn air because they're lying in bed sleeping. But please remember this fact: they too fought wars with their parents every morning during their teenage years due to insufficient sweet sleep.

The message that neuroscientists who study sleep want to convey about 'zero-period classes' is clear: if they wake up too early in the morning, teenagers can never enjoy going to school.

Jung Jae-seung, Guest Editorial Board Member, KAIST Department of Bio and Brain Engineering Professor
jsjeong@kaist.ac.kr"

  "translated_text": "My daughter learns Chinese over the phone from a Chinese instructor living in Qingdao [a coastal city in eastern China]. However, as she became familiar with Korean circumstances, she realized the hagwon was taking excessive profits. So she made a proposal to students: if they took classes directly without going through the hagwon, she would cut the tuition in half. From the students' calculation standpoint, there was no reason to refuse. This is one scene of 'globalization' vividly unfolding in our household.

Carrefour Boycott is a Double-Edged Sword

What implications does the nationalism, or what they call patriotism, that has been rampant in China around the Beijing Olympics have in the era of globalization? A Carrefour boycott movement is currently underway in China. It has a strong retaliatory character against the Olympic torch being extinguished by pro-Tibet protesters in Paris last month. Chinese people resolved to make May 1st, Labor Day, a 'day not to go to Carrefour,' and indeed Carrefour stores became empty and sales plummeted.

The Carrefour boycott began when text messages of unknown origin spread claiming that 'Carrefour's major shareholders are providing financial support to the Dalai Lama, and France supports Tibetan independence.' This raises two questions. First, did Carrefour really provide financial support to the Dalai Lama? Carrefour officially stated, 'We have never once provided financial support to the Dalai Lama.' But it was useless. It's similar to the situation in Korea where internet agitation works well, treating all American beef as if it's all mad cow disease beef.

Second, will the Carrefour boycott deal a blow to Carrefour and France? The Chinese government has essentially provided an answer to this. China's Ministry of Commerce revealed that 95% of products distributed in Carrefour stores in China are made in China, and 99% of all employees are Chinese. If so, the main victims of the Carrefour boycott should be seen as Chinese manufacturers, Carrefour's Chinese employees, and Chinese consumers. This is a case that specifically shows China is no longer outside the sphere of globalization.

China, which joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) in December 2001, is currently the world's fourth-largest economy and trading power by GDP, and ranks first in foreign exchange reserves and greenhouse gas emissions. China, 'the world's factory,' was the top contributor to global price stability until recently before raw material-driven inflation occurred. This was because it was the largest supplier of 'cheap goods' that people around the world buy and use. Former American journalist Sara Bongiorni concluded in her book 'A Year Without Made in China,' which chronicles her experience of surviving a year without buying Chinese products, that America without China doesn't exist. Even without the Beijing Olympics, a world without China has already become impossible to exist. Of course, China without the world is also unimaginable.

Due to the Discord Between Growth and Political Powerlessness?

In an era when humanity is enjoying the greatest prosperity in history, the 'nationalism' being displayed by young people in China, the greatest beneficiary of this era, is as incongruous as flowers blooming out of season. Some evaluate the so-called balinghou [post-1980s] generation, who grew up fully benefiting from China's economic growth, as a generation filled with pride in their homeland. However, Japanese scholar Takahara Motoaki views the nationalist tendencies of China's younger generation as 'a combination of mania from economic growth and depression from political powerlessness stemming from an undemocratic system.' I tend to agree with this opinion.

The phenomenon of globalization's beneficiaries being inclined toward nationalism is indeed paradoxical. However, the Moscow Olympics or Los Angeles Olympics, which were held only halfway due to ideological issues, cannot be repeated now. There are many Western companies sponsoring the Beijing Olympics. The interests of the Beijing Olympics and Western companies are intertwined. All the more reason why China's young people need to understand something: that they are able to enjoy today's benefits because China pursued reform and opening up and actively participated in the flow of globalization."

Universities that were negative about introducing the admissions officer system until January have suddenly come forward saying they will increase admissions officer selections. Educational authorities, who had been actively encouraging the adoption of admissions officers, are now saying they will impose disadvantages if too many are introduced. To provide information for understanding the admissions officer system correctly for test-takers exposed to this confusion, I would like to offer the following.

The admissions officer system is a more detailed organization of content that has already been implemented in existing extracurricular admissions. It's not about doing something new, but about changing one's perspective. In particular, one must break away from the get-rich-quick mentality that doing just one thing really well, like TOEFL or academic competitions, can get you into your desired university.

In admissions officer selections, potential related to one's major or career path is important. The ways admissions officer selections differ from previous extracurricular selections are as follows.

First, only official materials are not what matters. While previous extracurricular selections only utilized grades or materials received from high school, now activities from elementary and middle school are also reflected through personal statements, recommendation letters, and interviews.

Second, rather than one definite extracurricular activity, engaging in various on- and off-campus activities related to one's major is helpful. Also, there is a need to actively participate in off-campus activities rather than cookie-cutter on-campus activities.

Third, it is advantageous to establish application plans for one's career path or department in advance. It is good to establish a definite career plan by the latest during one's first year of high school.

Fourth, the weight of personal statements has increased. There is a need to write personal statements in advance like writing a diary and continuously supplement them. Relying on hagwon education [Korea's private tutoring industry] after becoming a high school senior is now meaningless.

Fifth, the weight of recommendation letters also increases. It is important to continuously consult about one's situation and build trust so that homeroom teachers or principals who will provide recommendations can understand one's strengths and weaknesses.

Sixth, all records must be left in school records. It is important to manage future hopes and career paths consistently and to steadily engage in one volunteer activity. The student evaluation section by the homeroom teacher recorded at the very end of school records also needs to be carefully checked.

Seventh, reading activities are a very important factor. When looking at potential, there is no better material than reading for measuring indirect experience. Some schools are already intentionally combining reading with school records [GPA] exams.

In admissions officer selections, the weight of school records overall will be lower than at present. This is because potential or the school's ideal human image is reflected in some form. Also, there is a high possibility that it will not be reflected by simple grades alone. In the case of mathematics departments, various factors such as raw scores and rankings in mathematics can be reflected more precisely.

Major subjects, especially major-related subjects, will be emphasized over all subjects. Humanities tracks will emphasize English, Korean, and social studies, while science tracks will emphasize math, science, and English, and there may be differences by department. However, depending on the school, there may be cases where school records become more important, so it is important to carefully examine admissions guidelines.

For preparing extracurricular activities, which are carrying even greater weight in admissions officer selections, it would be good to follow these principles.

First, priorities must be set. Priority 0 is things related to CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] and school records. In the case of English, TEPS will likely be more advantageous than TOEFL. TEPS has the advantages of high similarity to CSAT and requiring less regular preparation time. Of course, if CSAT scores are not good and one must enter university through English, TOEFL should be prioritized exceptionally. In the case of mathematics, if preparing for the Korean Mathematical Olympiad (KMO), it is advantageous to focus on the first round, which helps with CSAT preparation.

For humanities track students, while studying Korean history for first-year school records and doing advanced learning to take the Korean History Certification Test would also be a good strategy. Korean Language Certification Test or economics competitions are also good.

Second is things related to one's major or career path. Third, it is good to start with things that don't require particularly much time for preparation. Volunteer activities, club activities, and leadership activities are advantageous to take care of since they must be done anyway while living school life. In the case of reading activities too, it would be helpful to establish curriculum-linked, major-related reading plans and read them bit by bit during spare time in terms of managing reading records in school records.

Lee Hae-woong, Director of Time Education Hyst College Entrance Research Institute"

The key to effective extracurricular activities lies in leadership and creativity. Students should consistently engage in two or three activities starting from 9th and 10th grades. Students should identify their areas of interest and what they want to study in university, and from lower grades, they can participate in summer programs with high reputations in those fields or create their own clubs. The U.S. government, NASA, and many prestigious universities offer summer programs. There are many programs that not only high school students but also elementary and middle school students can participate in.

○ SAT I: Must prepare from 1st year high school

The SAT is a test that evaluates the critical thinking skills and academic potential necessary to perform university-level work in the United States. It is divided into SAT I, which evaluates logical reasoning, and SAT II, which tests subject-specific knowledge. Typically, SAT scores determine the level of universities students can apply to. The ACT (a college entrance exam administered by the nonprofit organization ACT Inc.) is also a U.S. college entrance exam like the SAT. The ACT is a test that evaluates academic knowledge based on curriculum content. Even if students take the test multiple times, they can submit only their highest score. The SAT is administered a total of 7 times per year (6 times in Korea), but because the preparation period is long, students must prepare starting at least from 10th grade (1st year high school).

○ SAT II: Must plan to obtain scores in 2-3 subjects

Some prestigious universities require SAT II scores in 2 subjects, and some even require SAT II scores in 3 subjects. While not mandatory, submitting these scores when applying is helpful. Since some universities don't require SAT II scores, if preparation time is short, it's advantageous to achieve high scores on SAT I.

○ TOEFL: High scores are helpful

Students whose native language is not English have their English proficiency evaluated through TOEFL scores. Early study abroad students and international school students are often exempt. If SAT I Critical Reading section scores are low, submitting high TOEFL scores is helpful.

○ AP: Must study systematically according to test schedule

AP is a system where high school students take college-level courses (selected from 37 subjects) and take exams administered by the nonprofit College Board, and if they receive 4-5 points out of a perfect score of 5, universities recognize those subjects as earned credits and refer to them in admissions screening. Because Ivy League universities require AP scores, in Korea, Korean Minjok Leadership Academy teaches AP subjects as regular classes, and various foreign language high schools teach AP subjects as after-school classes. The exam is administered once each year in May. Because it overlaps with SAT II subjects, it's efficient to take SAT II and AP in the same subjects.

○ College application essays: Must connect themes with experiences

Students must write 5-6 essays as part of their admissions applications, including a 'Common Essay' that addresses common themes required by all U.S. universities and 'Supplement Essays' with different themes for each school. To leave a strong impression on admissions officers, students must connect essay themes with original experiences to unfold their stories. Essays should be written so that a clear picture emerges of what values the student holds after reading them.

**Providing completely different customized textbooks for each student**
**Helping prevent repeated mistakes in weak areas**

CEO Choi began restructuring System Math from early last year when he started participating in the company's management. What he pondered most was the company's vision. CEO Choi said, "Even students with good math grades have weak areas," adding, "I wanted to create a 'tool' that would help good students do even better and help struggling students do better than before." After about a year of effort, they independently developed 'e-CT' (education-Computerized Tomography).

Once the e-CT assessment is complete, analysis reports in table and graph format are provided so students' abilities and levels can be understood at a glance. The analysis reports show how one's math ability compares to national averages, top 30%, and regional averages. Detailed analysis and prescriptions by domain and ability are also provided.

Level-based progress textbooks are composed of 5 levels. Considering the increasing proportion of descriptive and essay-type questions, they intensively reinforced completion-type, step-by-step, and descriptive problems.

In the first stage, a certain multiple of the enrollment capacity is selected based on school records, and in the second stage, final successful candidates are selected by combining school records with interview scores. Not only written exams but also modified forms of written tests such as oral interviews asking about subject knowledge or aptitude tests are prohibited. {
  "translated_title": "[Prime TOWN] Math Creative Thinking Skills Commandment #1: 'Build Fundamental Conceptual Strength'",
  "translated_text": "Concept-focused learning essential for elementary math... Avoid obsession with advanced study
Build skills step by step for gifted education centers → international middle schools and special purpose high schools
Math play using manipulatives such as 3D shapes and dice helps develop elementary students' creative thinking skills. An elementary student is studying with the creative thinking math textbook 'FACTO' and math manipulatives. Photo provided by Time Education Co., Ltd.

《Parents' interest in gifted education centers is growing year by year. In April, the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology announced admissions guidelines stating that all 25 university-affiliated gifted education centers nationwide plan to select students through 100% admissions officer screening. While Olympiad and competition awards can no longer be recorded in school records, the fact that students received education at gifted classes or gifted education centers can still be recorded, making gifted education centers a particular focus of interest among students aiming for international middle schools or special purpose high schools.

In the 'giftedness assessment,' one of the gifted education center admission processes, problems that evaluate creative thinking skills rather than traditional mathematical intellectual ability are primarily featured. Parents are curious about how to study to improve their children's creative thinking skills and what materials to use to prepare for admission to gifted education centers. Let's find clues to creative thinking education methods through Time Education Co., Ltd.'s creative thinking math content specialist 'Mathian Research Institute.'》

[Tip 1] Don't be impatient about advanced learning
Most students rush to advance quickly through the curriculum. Students, parents, and teachers alike share this tendency. Many students think that elementary math is simply calculation-focused and that they just need to be good at substituting into formulas and calculating. However, it's important to remember that important mathematical concepts appear during elementary school. Elementary math absolutely requires concept-focused learning.

Let's use first-grade level subtraction problems as an example.

Most students and parents find it difficult to recognize the difference between these two problems. They think these are similar subtraction problems with only different expressions. The upper problem is the 'removal method,' asking about remaining butterflies when two fly away from seven butterflies, while the lower problem is the 'comparison method,' comparing the difference between six and two to ask which is more. The comparison method can be seen as an easier way to understand the concept of subtraction than the removal method. Since students usually solve subtraction using the commonly taught removal method, error rates increase when comparison method problems are presented.

Let's examine how accurate conceptual understanding of subtraction helps in problem solving. The following problem is a type frequently featured in gifted education centers and competitions.

Students would typically draw the 30th stone and count the white and black stones. However, using the comparison method principle of subtraction makes the problem easy to solve. Comparing the number of white and black stones at each even-numbered position reveals that black stones are always one more. In even-numbered stone pyramids, if you think of one row of white stones and the row of black stones directly below as one group, each group always has one more black stone, so at the 30th position, there are 15 more black stones.

Concepts are both simple and important. By building concepts step by step, mathematical strength to solve high-difficulty problems is developed. Remember that the basic concepts of math learned in the appropriate grade are more important than advanced learning.

[Tip 2] Perfect from the start? It's okay to solve again!
Writing math problems all over the blackboard and explaining solution processes - this is a typical math class scene. However, this is not a desirable teaching method.

Creative thinking skills are not developed by solving many problems perfectly. Even if solving fewer problems, it's important to spend sufficient time on each problem and have time to think. Whether the answer is right or wrong, thinking skills improve through that process.

Let's use a parent and student as an example. A mother and child came for counseling at a math hagwon. The student who took the diagnostic test was quite smart. The parent said, 'I didn't teach anything special - I just bought my child a creative thinking textbook (FACTO) and graded it.' The parent didn't immediately show the solution process for problems the student got wrong, but had the student continue solving problems. After finishing the textbook, the student solved the wrong problems again from the beginning. On the second attempt, the student correctly solved 50% of the problems that were wrong initially. After finishing the textbook this way and solving problems again, this time the student solved everything except about 10% of the problems they didn't know initially.

It's very important to finish the textbook even if there are wrong problems. Also, additional problem-solving skills will be developed through that process. When having children solve wrong problems again, you can confirm that your child's problem-solving ability improves.

[Tip 3] Become friends with math through play!
Many parents worry about children who can't sit still at their desks even for a moment. Lower elementary grades are when children aren't yet accustomed to studying at desks. At this time, creative thinking skills can be developed through games and manipulatives.

Play using manipulatives such as 3D shapes, dice, and magnetic tangrams helps develop spatial perception and reasoning abilities. Among these, let's look at 'pentomino,' a game made using blocks.

Pentomino refers to blocks made by connecting five unit cubes together. It's a compound word from 'pento,' meaning five in ancient Greek, and 'mino,' meaning piece. It's a method of creating various forms using 12 blocks of different shapes made by connecting 5 unit cubes. Various forms such as alphabets, penguins, camels, and roosters can be made. Through such play, children not only enhance mathematical reasoning ability but also find fun and interest in logical thinking. However, when using mathematical manipulatives, it's necessary to accurately recognize the child's thinking level and engage in activities appropriate to their level.

Han Heon-jo, Director of 'Mathian' Creative Thinking Math Research Institute, Time Education Co., Ltd.
Author of elementary creative thinking math textbook Mathian 'FACTO'"

One should first consider whether student record-focused tracks or essay-focused tracks are more advantageous, then examine universities afterward.

There are various types within both student record-centered and essay-centered tracks. After identifying one's strengths and weaknesses, one should choose the most advantageous track among school record-focused, essay-focused, and special talent tracks, and understand the additional characteristics these tracks possess. For example, one must carefully examine whether school record-focused tracks also reflect extracurricular areas, or whether essay-focused tracks consider CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] minimum grade requirements.

Ability Diagnosis + Track Selection → Customized Study Plan → University-Specific Test Preparation

Must establish study plan suited to admissions track and target department

Once an admissions track is selected, one must carefully examine the selection requirements that track demands and create a study plan accordingly. For example, Seoul National University's 2011 Regional Balanced Selection track selects twice the number of candidates based solely on student record academic grades in the first stage, then conducts admissions officer screening in the second stage. Additionally, Seoul National University announced it would select students faithful to classes within school boundaries rather than those with so-called flashy 'specs' like contest awards in its admissions officer system. Understanding such university policies and establishing study plans accordingly is important.

Students preparing cross-field applications should confirm the format and content of university-specific essay tests and apply according to their strengths and weaknesses. KICE Director Kim Sung-yeol emphasized the connection with EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials, saying "EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] textbooks were the starting point for (test question) ideas," and entrance exam companies agreed, saying "We view about half as direct or indirect linked questions." With the higher linkage rate, many opinions suggested that the perceived difficulty was generally easier compared to last year's June mock evaluation. However, there were also many reactions that Math 'Ga' [advanced math track] and Foreign Language sections were challenging.

Regarding this, Shin Il-yong, head of KICE's Test Development Research Division who was in charge of question development, said "We have established a policy to maintain this year's CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] difficulty at the same level as last year," adding "The basic direction is to make Foreign Language, which was difficult last year, difficult, and Language and Math, which were easy, easy."

○ EBS linkage rate over 50%

This test was the first one developed after KICE, the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] development institution, announced it would link tests with EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials. KICE announced that the EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] linkage rate was 50-56% by subject area. In the Language section, the classical novel 'Nakseongbiryong (洛城飛龍)' that appeared as a passage and question in the EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] textbook 'Internet CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] Special Lecture' pages 168-170 was used as the passage for question 48. Math 'Ga' [advanced math track] question 7 was created with almost the same graph shape as appeared in EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials. In the Foreign Language section, problems that used EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] textbook passages directly also appeared.

Cho Mi-jeong, Education Research Director at Kim Young-il Education Consulting, said "There are still more than 5 months until the CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], so there may be students who are not yet familiar with past exam problems themselves," adding "It seems KICE tried hard to maintain a linkage rate of over 50%." Lee Man-gi, Evaluation Director at Yuhway Jungang Education, evaluated that "Problems linked not only to EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials but also to lectures noticeably increased."

KICE Director Kim Sung-yeol said "During the September mock evaluation and November CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], we can adjust linkage methods and utilization ratios by method. [Image caption: EBS Mock Evaluation Closely Resembling EBS Materials
Question 11 from the June CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] mock evaluation conducted on the 10th (left) is similar to question 3 on page 123 of the EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] textbook 'Internet CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] Writing & Vocabulary·Grammar.' ○ Don't rely solely on EBS materials

As the connection with EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials became visually confirmed, entrance exam experts advised that strategies centered on EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials are needed to prepare for this year's CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam]. KICE announced "Problems from other reference books are classified as past exam problems and excluded from question development targets, but problems from EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials will be actively reflected." Kim Myeong-chan, Director of Jongno Academy's Entrance Strategy Research Institute, said "To receive good scores on this year's CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam], students must deeply understand and analyze EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] textbook passages and analyze question types."

  "translated_title": "Seokbong Chinese Characters Representative Park Han-shin: 'What Should Be the Goal of Chinese Character Learning?'",
  "translated_text": "Students who had become university students came to visit the hagwon on Teacher's Day. While catching up, one student very proudly boasted that he had studied for 2 months at an intensive hagwon and obtained a Level 2 Chinese character certification. I felt both pleased and proud, but I was also curious about his actual Chinese character ability, so I asked him to write 'Hanshin (漢神)' in Chinese characters.

Something quite shocking happened. He wrote the character '漢' as '韓', and couldn't write the character '神' at all. When writing '韓', he couldn't even complete the '韋' (leather) radical at the bottom, which was even more astounding. He couldn't properly read any of the Chinese character signs on the street either. What started as a joke ended up being quite upsetting. I sharply pointed out: 'Don't go around saying you got Level 2 certification anymore. Your Chinese character ability isn't Level 2—it's Level 5.'

It seems that even with terrible Chinese character ability, if you focus solely on obtaining Level 2 certification for 2 months, it's possible to achieve it. But I wonder what meaning such Level 2 acquisition really holds. Considering the expensive hagwon fees [approximately $150-300 USD per month] and time invested, the results are far too disappointing. Most importantly, since they crammed and memorized Chinese characters for hundreds of hours over 2 months including classes, they probably never want to see Chinese characters again for the rest of their lives. I thought that this kind of learning, rather than being beneficial to individuals, could actually cause great harm in the long run.

So what kind of learning outcomes should proper Chinese character study produce? What can we say is the goal of correct Chinese character learning? First, if someone has obtained Level 2 certification, they should be able to use Korean vocabulary freely. As you well know, 50-70% of Korean vocabulary consists of Chinese character words. Chinese character learning should lead to etymologically organizing these vocabularies to improve Korean language proficiency. Therefore, simply memorizing 2,000 characters has little meaning. Of course, if even that were done properly, there would be no occasion for a teacher to scold a student.

Second, we should set rich literary creative activities as a learning goal. Our people have been a cultured nation that has excelled in literature and arts since ancient times. In the pre-writing period, we proved our excellence through paintings and sculptures, and through Chinese characters, we blossomed Chinese literature rivaling that of China, taking pride in our superiority.

In terms of continuing this tradition, if one has properly studied Chinese characters, they should be able to write diaries in Chinese characters and compose Chinese poetry. Additionally, they should be able to read classics written in Chinese characters without difficulty. Chinese character learning has meaning and value when it becomes the starting point for literary activities like this.

Beyond the learning goals of vocabulary usage and literary creation, what's needed is learning that helps with school records [GPA] Chinese literature and CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] Chinese literature. This too can be called an important learning goal. As one learns Chinese characters, Chinese literature ability should grow, and basic skills should be developed so there's no difficulty studying Chinese literature for school records and CSAT. Finally, learning Chinese characters should inspire the desire to study higher levels.

Maintaining intellectual interest to foster continuous learning motivation for Chinese character study is also an important learning goal.

We have proverbs that say 'dried persimmons are sweet for immediate eating' and 'trying to travel three days' journey in one day leads to lying sick for ten days.' For those who need certifications immediately, the temptation of intensive Chinese character courses that finish quickly may be great, but it would be desirable to properly learn Chinese characters at professional educational institutions that can realize the educational goals introduced above.

Source: Seokbong Chinese Characters Representative Park Han-shin

  "translated_text": "Hagwon law revision likely to be promulgated next month... College prep consulting companies and online lecture companies also classified as 'hagwons'
The partial revision bill of the Act on the Establishment and Operation of Hagwons and Extracurricular Tutoring passed the National Assembly's Education, Science and Technology Committee on the 11th. If this revision passes the plenary session in April, the burden of hagwon tuition fees will be greatly reduced. Going forward, one must carefully examine hagwon tuition fees, online lecture fees, and college prep consulting costs that local education offices will disclose. Dong-A Ilbo DB

《The burden of hagwon education costs is expected to decrease starting from the second half of this year at the earliest. The 'Partial Revision Bill of the Act on the Establishment and Operation of Hagwons and Extracurricular Tutoring,' created for transparent operation of private hagwons, passed the full meeting of the National Assembly's Education, Science and Technology Committee on the 11th. It is predicted that some hagwon education cost reduction effects will appear once the revision is promulgated through the National Assembly plenary session next month. This revision bill's main points include: △requiring hagwons to include in their tuition fees certain expenses previously collected separately from tuition, such as 'essay correction fees,' 'essay instruction fees,' and 'supplementary class fees,' and report these costs to provincial and metropolitan education superintendents △mandating the issuance of receipts for all costs paid to hagwons, including textbook fees and tuition fees △including companies that provide consulting necessary for advancing to higher schools and online lecture companies that teach elementary, middle, and high school subjects in the concept of 'hagwons.' What should parents carefully check on hagwon fee receipts that their children bring home?》

○ Roundabout tuition fees disappear... Check the receipts!

Going forward, receipts can be obtained unconditionally for all costs paid to hagwons. Hagwons must mandatorily issue receipts for tuition fee details and textbook purchase contents.

Once you receive a receipt, carefully check whether there are additional expenses beyond tuition fees. This is because various expenses that were additionally charged beyond hagwon tuition fees until now will be bundled under the name 'tuition fees, etc.' and disclosed on receipts. Being disclosed on receipts means they become subject to legal regulation.

Some hagwons have until now demanded additional costs under the names of △essay correction fees △supplementary class fees △essay instruction fees △test application fees △textbook fees △transportation fees △specific test fees, etc., beyond tuition fees. Some hagwons even forced payment in 'cash' only, not credit cards, for these items. This loophole worked because hagwon tuition fees are subject to education office regulation.

Currently, the average price of monthly tuition fees that education offices nationwide have determined to be appropriate is about 90,000 won [approximately $68 USD]. This means that regardless of subject, if a hagwon conducts a total of 21 50-minute classes during a month, it should receive an average of 90,000 won [approximately $68 USD] (though it varies by education office, ranging from as little as 70,000 won [approximately $53 USD] to as much as 120,000 won [approximately $91 USD]). However, in reality, quite a few hagwons have charged various additional costs on top of this appropriate tuition fee, causing parents to sometimes pay several times more than the tuition fee.

A Ministry of Education official said, "We will include supplementary class fees, essay instruction fees, etc., that were separately charged beyond tuition fees, in the tuition fees," adding, "Once the revision is promulgated, each education office will investigate hagwon fees and then set appropriate tuition fees suitable for local conditions."

Going forward, when purchasing textbooks at hagwons, you must request receipts. Until now, some hagwons sold textbooks that cost 5,000 won [approximately $4 USD] in the market for 15,000 won [approximately $11 USD] at the hagwon, and profited by selling textbooks copied on A4 paper at expensive prices. However, once textbook fee receipt issuance becomes mandatory, textbooks can be purchased at reasonable prices equivalent to market book prices or printing and copying costs.

○ Online lectures and consulting companies also classified as 'hagwons'... Pay attention to provincial and metropolitan education office websites!

Starting from the second half of this year, check the relevant provincial or metropolitan education office website before choosing a hagwon. You can verify hagwon tuition fees in advance. Starting three months after the revision's promulgation, provincial and metropolitan education office websites plan to disclose all hagwon names, locations, educational courses, subjects, capacity, class hours, and tuition fees. If the tuition fees disclosed on the website differ from the actual tuition fees the hagwon demands, you can report to the illegal hagwon education reporting center.

It's also noteworthy that companies providing college prep and admissions consulting and internet lecture companies are included in 'hagwons.' Going forward, all costs demanded by college prep consulting or online lecture companies will be subject to 'hagwon fee' regulation. Until now, expensive consulting costing 500,000 to 1 million won [approximately $380-760 USD] per hour has flourished in some quarters. However, from now on, these consulting companies must also report consulting costs to provincial and metropolitan education offices, so price decreases are expected.

Provincial and metropolitan education offices plan to conduct on-site inspections of regional college prep consulting companies, then calculate appropriate costs and present guidelines. If companies report costs that are deemed too high, investigations into those companies will begin. One college prep consulting official said, "The appropriate amount for consulting costs that provincial and metropolitan education offices will present is predicted to be under 200,000 won [approximately $152 USD] per session."

Online lecture fees are also expected to become lower. Currently, online lecture fees operated by private educational companies vary greatly depending on packages, ranging from as little as 30,000 won [approximately $23 USD] to as much as 200,000 won [approximately $152 USD]. A Ministry of Education official said, "It's unreasonable to charge such high tuition fees while replaying the same lectures," adding, "We plan to calculate appropriate tuition fees for online lectures using different methods from offline hagwons." Internet lecture fees will also be disclosed on websites under education office management."

  "translated_text": "Inquiry subjects reduced by 1 subject creates variable for '1% perfect scorers goal'
"Number of test-takers difficult to predict"… 'EBS linkage' to remain 70% as planned

The 2012 CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) to be administered on November 10 this year will be designed to be easy enough to produce about 1% perfect scorers in Korean Language, Mathematics, and Foreign Language sections, as originally planned. The EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) linkage ratio will be maintained at 70% like last year.

The Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation announced these basic implementation plans for CSAT on the 30th. Seong Tae-je, the newly appointed head of the evaluation institute, stated, "Starting this year, we will make maximum efforts to maintain exam difficulty consistently and increase predictability for students and parents by targeting about 1% perfect scorers in each subject area."

○ 1% Perfect Scorers, Inquiry Subjects Are Key

Director Seong showed a cautious attitude regarding Social Studies and Science inquiry areas. He said, "Since the maximum number of elective subjects in inquiry areas has been reduced to 3, it's difficult to predict the number of test-takers. We'll need to see the selection trends in the June mock exam first. However, we plan to make the questions easier than in previous years."

In last year's CSAT, which was evaluated as difficult, the perfect scorer rates were Korean Language 0.06%, Mathematics 'Ga' [advanced track] 0.02%, and Foreign Language 0.21%. Even in the 2010 CSAT, which was considered easy, the perfect scorer rates were Korean Language 0.24%, Mathematics 'Na' [standard track] 0.84%, and Foreign Language 0.74%, all falling short of 1%.

If the evaluation institute achieves the announced 1% level for each area, this year's CSAT will be easier than last year's. The renewed emphasis on 1% this time is interpreted as a strong commitment to make this year's CSAT easier.

EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) materials linked to CSAT have been significantly reduced from 45 to 24 volumes combining Korean Language, Mathematics, and Foreign Language. Director Seong said, "Last year we created questions assuming test-takers would study all EBS materials, but students actually couldn't do that, and there was criticism that there were too many materials. This year should improve since we've reduced the materials."

○ Changes in This Year's CSAT

First, the Mathematics section's testing scope will change. In Mathematics 'Ga', mainly taken by science track students, elective subjects will be eliminated and questions will come from both Calculus and Statistics, and Geometry and Vectors. Mathematics 'Na', taken by humanities students, will add Calculus and Statistics Basics in addition to Mathematics I.

Director Seong said, "There may be concerns that the Mathematics section will become more difficult due to the changed testing scope, but we will strive to maintain difficulty consistently."

While there was analysis that Mathematics would become a major variable for pass/fail decisions with the addition of Calculus and Statistics Basics to Mathematics 'Na', the explanation is that studying through regular school classes and EBS (Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media) will be sufficient to solve the problems without burdening test-takers.

Inquiry subject electives will be reduced from 4 to 3 subjects starting this year. Total testing time will also be shortened by 30 minutes, ending the exam at 5:35 PM.

○ CSAT Importance Actually Increases

Even if CSAT becomes easier, it would be wrong to assume that CSAT's importance in admissions will decrease accordingly. Major universities in Seoul are trending toward increasing CSAT weight in regular admissions.

Most implement 'priority selection' where 50-70% of regular admission slots are filled based solely on CSAT scores. Many universities have also strengthened minimum CSAT score requirements for early admissions.

In an 'easy CSAT' with many tied high scorers, mistakes become even more fatal. Kim Myeong-chan, director of Jongro Academy's [a major hagwon chain] admissions strategy research institute, said, "For upper-middle tier students, efforts to reduce mistakes are more important than anything. If Korean Language, Mathematics, and Foreign Language are easy, inquiry subjects could become variables, so preparation is necessary."

Lee Yeong-deok, director of Daesung Academic Development Research Institute [associated with a major hagwon], advised, "Even in an easy CSAT, some questions will be made difficult to secure discrimination among top scorers. Top-tier students need to prepare for this.""

  "translated_text": "Students of similar levels gather for arts/PE to essay writing and debate
Start by paying high membership fees... Headaches when skill gaps emerge

Ms. Park (41, Songpa-gu, Seoul), a working mother with a middle school first-grader son in the top academic tier, recently 'broke ties' with three close parent friends. The relationship that had been strong since her child was in first grade of elementary school went awry because of 'team classes.'

Last weekend afternoon, Ms. Park ran into her son's friend, Student A, on the street. When she asked "Where are you headed?", Student A looked flustered and mumbled. Sensing something strange, Ms. Park called Student A's mother. When she asked with a laugh, "What are you having A do behind my back?", the mother confessed, "I've wanted to tell you for a while but I'm sorry. Actually, they're doing team classes excluding only your son."

Student A and several friends, who had been in the elementary school top tier group, had started essay writing team classes last September before entering middle school. However, they excluded only Ms. Park's son, as she couldn't provide 'rides' (taking turns driving to the team class location) due to her work. Ms. Park's son was the undisputed number one student in the entire school. Ms. Park exploded in anger, saying "I can't tolerate not only that they deceived me, but that they kept it secret for over six months, even telling the children never to say anything."

As group classes have expanded in school settings recently and debate and presentation performance assessments have become important, 'team classes' centered on essay writing and debate are gaining popularity. Parents aim for learning synergy effects through team classes composed of relatively high-level children. Dong-A Ilbo DB

Conflicts among parents over 'team classes' are intensifying. Team classes refer to group tutoring where students of similar levels gather for subjects ranging from arts and PE to English and math.

Team classes have gained popularity recently, centered on essay writing, debate, and creative thinking math, as group classes have expanded in educational settings and debate and presentation performance assessments have become important. Additionally, as English and science debate competitions, English debate contests, and Model UN conferences that can build college entrance portfolios have greatly increased, team classes to prepare for these are rapidly growing, especially among top-tier students.

Team classes where students of similar levels gather to aim for synergy effects. However, conflicts over team classes among parents are endless. What are the reasons?

Ms. Kim (41, Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], Gangnam-gu [an affluent district in Seoul], Seoul), a housewife with a top-tier second-year middle school daughter, cited 'level differences' as a factor in conflicts. Ms. Kim formed a team to compete in English debate contests for her daughter who aims to enter a foreign language high school. In debate, the role of 'speakers' is very important. The first speaker must capture the evaluators' attention and present the topic, while the second speaker must logically rebut the opposing team's first statement.

Although they formed a team with top-tier students met at a debate hagwon, there were still skill differences within the group. After three months of team classes, they entered a competition but were eliminated. This was because the third speaker, who should have counter-rebutted the opposing team's second speaker's rebuttal, failed to perform their role properly.

The parents decided to remove that student from the team classes and soon recruited another student. Ms. Kim said, "We spent a large amount on team classes, so we can't suffer losses because of a child who doesn't meet the level," and "hagwons divide classes through level tests so you just follow that, but teams are arbitrarily organized by mothers, so conflicts over children's levels frequently lead to team dissolution."

Conflicts over strict team joining and withdrawal processes are also endless, as teams are formed around well-regarded instructors in the area.

One math olympiad prep instructor set the condition that five students must continue for a full year before starting classes. The total membership fee paid by the team is 1.5 million won [approximately $1,150 USD] per month. Five fifth-grade elementary students were assembled.

When the classes had been running for about four months, housewife Ms. B (Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], Gangnam-gu [an affluent district in Seoul], Seoul) had an opportunity to send her son abroad for language study. After talking with a senior mother, she postponed the study abroad by six months. The senior mother advised, "In this neighborhood, it's not like you're doing this for just a year or two and then leaving - mothers who break up teams get a reputation for having no manners and can never join team classes again. If you're going to quit, it's more comfortable to pay the remaining eight months' fees and then leave."

Ms. B said, "Since one team has to match membership fees of at least 1 million won [approximately $760 USD] to millions of won [approximately $2,000–8,000 USD] per month, when one person drops out mid-way, it burdens the remaining people," and "I was afraid I wouldn't survive in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry] if I acted without manners.""

  "translated_text": "Enlarge
After the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology designated Korean history as a mandatory subject for high school students entering next year, academic circles are raising the criticism that biased content should have been corrected first.
Opinions are also raised that proper history education is difficult without designating it as mandatory on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam), along with concerns about fairness issues with other social studies subjects.
○ New Korean History Textbooks Also Biased
Education Minister Lee Ju-ho cited as background for making Korean history mandatory that "if you don't know history well, you cannot respond to distortions by China and Japan."
However, Lee Ju-young, professor emeritus of history at Konkuk University, pointed out that "the current textbooks should have been properly established first before implementation. Doing it in this state could instill wrong historical perspectives in students." He added that "even if Korean history mandates are delayed slightly, a preparation process is necessary."
Park Ji-hyang, professor of Western history at Seoul National University, also said, "Because of the Dokdo issue, it feels like the government was pushed by public opinion and handled things too hastily," adding "Given the continued criticism of left-bias in Korean history textbooks, proper textbooks should have been developed first." Kim Ki-bong, professor of history at Kyonggi University, pointed out that "there seems to have been no proper agreement between the executive and legislative branches in the mandatory designation process."
The fact that high school Korean history textbooks in use from this year show biased descriptions was also revealed when this newspaper reviewed six types together with experts.
▶See A3 page, February 16th
A3 page [New Korean History Textbooks Also Left-Biased] Specify Concrete Incidents of Korean-US Forces
[New Korean History Textbooks Also Left-Biased] Approval Process Was Not Smooth
For example, Mirae-N Culture Group's textbook did not sufficiently explain that North Korea had essentially formed an independent government (February 1946) before President Syngman Rhee's Jeongeup speech (June 1946) about a separate government, causing misunderstanding that South Korea provided the cause for division.
North Korea's public executions and political prison camps, and the Aung San National Cemetery terrorist incident were each covered by only one publisher. The KAL bombing incident and the 1996 Gangneung armed infiltration incident did not appear at all.
Lee Young-hoon, professor in the Department of Economics at Seoul National University and author of New Right history books, pointed out that "current Korean history textbooks are mostly occupied by post-opening period and Joseon history, and biased narratives are also problematic, plus they lack parts related to our current lives and necessary for enhancing patriotism," adding "if mandates are forced through while leaving these problems as they are, it will amplify the problems of history education."
○ Who Will Study If Not CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) Mandatory?
Criticism is also raised that if Korean history is not designated as mandatory on the CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam), few test-takers will choose it, making it difficult to expect the effect of strengthening history education.
This is because there likely won't be many test-takers who will choose and diligently study Korean history, which is more burdensome in terms of time and volume than other social studies subjects.
In fact, test-takers have continuously decreased since the 2005 academic year when Korean history became a CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam) elective subject. It was 27.7% of all test-takers in the 2005 academic year, but 10.5% in 2008 and 9.5% in 2011. Even in the March nationwide joint scholastic assessment for high school seniors, students who chose Korean history were 10.2% of the total.
Kang Min-seong, Korean history hagwon instructor at Visang Edu, said, "In actual CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam), even fewer test-takers choose Korean history. Currently, only Seoul National University and Pusan University require Korean history as a mandatory subject in college admissions. The Ministry of Education's policy is to recommend expanding Korean history requirements to the Korean Council for University Education.
However, one university official said, "If just the top 10 major universities make it mandatory, the number of test-takers would increase, but it would be difficult for other universities. Making Korean history, which most test-takers find difficult, mandatory could reduce application rates."
Fairness with other social studies subjects is also an issue. Professor Kim Ki-bong said, "The current curriculum is already focused on Korean, English, and math, and 12 subjects are gathered in the small pie of social studies, so problems are bound to arise if only Korean history is made mandatory. Resistance from other subjects like geography is severe."
Reporter Choi Ye-na yena@donga.com"

  "translated_title": "[O2/Field Experience] Online Lectures",
  "translated_text": ""Was that about 30 minutes?"... "It was only 8 minutes"
One minute felt like ten. My mind was full of things to say, but the same words just kept circling in my mouth. The online lecture stage, called the 'major leagues' of the hagwon industry. To find out how difficult it is, this reporter visited the studio of Megastudy, the industry leader. Reporter Shin Won-gun laputa@donga.com

Eloquent words pour forth in my mind. But the same words just circle in my mouth. My eyes meet the cold lens of the camera. The red light signaling 'on air' blinks. Meeting the camera's gaze doubles the pressure. My nose gets stuffy, my lips tremble. After about 3 minutes, my mouth goes dry and my throat burns. How do instructors who pour out words for over an hour endure without a single sip of water? Their skills are truly remarkable.

After about 5 minutes, I enter a state of 'selflessness.' I'm curious what I'm even saying. The blackboard seems to get bigger while I feel smaller. My hands are drenched in sweat, covered messily with colorful chalk dust. After finishing the lecture and taking a deep breath, I asked: "Was that about 30 minutes?" Son Eun-jin, managing director of Megastudy, smiled and said: "It wasn't even 8 minutes."

○ Thousands of applicants... Only 1-2 new faces

Internet lectures are called the 'major leagues' by hagwon instructors. As such, even debuting is difficult. The number of internet instructors belonging to industry leader Megastudy (last year's revenue approximately 245 billion won [approximately $185 million USD]) is about 230. However, new 'rookies' making their debut average only 1-2 per year. Last year alone, over 1,500 new instructors submitted applications, and even experienced instructors knocked on doors, but the 'internet wall' was too high. Among the applicants were elites including those in their 30s who graduated from prestigious university medical schools and those who earned doctoral degrees from prestigious American universities, but they too faced bitter disappointment.

Even after the difficult debut on the internet stage, the probability of survival is extremely low. Once you fall out of favor with the brutal real-time evaluations pouring in from students, it's hard to recover. One instructor said bitterly, "I taught offline for over 10 years, prepared for nearly a year, and then did internet lectures. But it took less than 10 minutes to receive notice of dismissal."

I was curious about what exactly made it so difficult. When I asked Megastudy's Managing Director Son, she replied, "Well, how about you try it yourself?" So I decided to experience being an online instructor.

○ The lecture goes awry... words and hands moving separately

On the afternoon of the 14th of last month at Megastudy's headquarters building in Seocho-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul [an affluent district in Seoul]. In the broadcast room on the first basement floor, 26 studios were displaying their majesty. The explanation was that most (70-80%) internet lectures are filmed directly at affiliated hagwon lecture sites, with only some done here. Even so, except for the lecture room reserved for this reporter, all were in 'on air' status.

For this reporter, a complete 'rookie' at lecturing, we decided to cover just one problem. The time would be around 10 minutes. The subject was the politics section within the social studies area. This was a consideration for the reporter who majored in political science in college.

The mentor role was taken by veteran instructor Ahn Sang-jong, who has been doing online lectures at Megastudy for nearly 10 years. At our first meeting, he told me to draw a map in my head. He meant that from the start to the end of the lecture, I should break it down by seconds and calculate what to say, when to pause, and what expressions to make. When I asked "Is that possible?" he replied with a smile: "Even instructors who are seasoned in the internet world work with lecture research teams, burning the midnight oil every day preparing lectures. Debut instructors usually take over six months just for preparation."

After about 30 minutes of explanation, I still couldn't grasp it. So I immediately switched to practice mode. From instructor Ahn, I learned the lecture content and basic delivery methods; from broadcast staff, I learned gaze management, hand gestures, and blackboard writing techniques.

Six problems were provided in the politics subject. The mission was to choose the one I was most confident about and explain it. This reporter chose a problem related to 'social contract theory' from the March national joint academic assessment. Having read related books in college and finding the concepts relatively clear, it seemed easier to explain.

After tidying my appearance neatly and applying simple makeup, the lecture began immediately. Perhaps because it had been over 10 years since I tutored as a college freshman, I was overly nervous. From the first words, my speech got tangled and the lecture went awry. Feeling it was hopeless, I asked to start over.

After taking a deep breath, I entered the second filming. I understood the content but was at a loss where to start explaining. So I hung my head low and just read through the entire problem first. Then came the concept explanation. The key was to accurately understand and explain the theories of Hobbes, Locke, and Rousseau, the philosophers who advocated social contract theory. I understood the characteristics of Hobbes's theory, but the theories of the other two were swirling in my head. Since I was confused, my words became redundantly long. The explanation became muddled and unclear. Writing on the blackboard was also harder than expected. My words and hands moved separately. I buried my head in the blackboard and kept writing, then realized: 'The instructors I saw in videos maintained eye contact with the camera while writing on the board...' But it was already spilled milk. Suddenly looking straight ahead would seem even more awkward, so I just became friends with the blackboard.

○ Smooth like singing, flavorful like waves

The lecture ended somehow. It took 7 minutes and 55 seconds. The perceived time felt five times longer. Sharp criticisms immediately followed from Managing Director Son and instructor Ahn. "The lecture should flow smoothly like singing and have impact like an action movie, but yours was bland." "First, you need to grab attention by hitting the key points in a deductive manner, but your introduction dragged." "Building trust comes first. If the instructor lacks confidence, students will turn away in less than a minute." "Your voice is too monotone. The tone and intonation should be flavorful like waves." Despite being relatively generous, the criticisms never stopped. "Still, you did well for a first time," came Managing Director Son's belated consolation. My face burned with embarrassment, and I couldn't lift my head.

A few days later, an evaluation report was delivered to the company. Megastudy's professional lecture evaluation team wrote it after watching this reporter's video. The evaluation categories were 'lecture ability, delivery, individuality, growth potential' - these four (▼ see 'Evaluation Report'). Managing Director Son said in a phone call, "In actual instructor evaluations, there are over 10 categories, and each category is scored." As if seeing this reporter shaking his head, she laughed and added: "If you have regrets, come tomorrow and film once more?" Without a second's hesitation, I replied: "That's okay. I'm satisfied with my current job.""
}

Last year, there was an incident at a neighborhood middle school where a second-year student was beaten by third-year students and suffered a ruptured intestine requiring six months of treatment. Because he had lived abroad and returned, he was one grade behind his former classmates, and the reason he was assaulted was that he spoke informally to them as he used to. The perpetrator students called out the victim and took turns keeping watch while beating him in a shopping center restroom past midnight. They said they stopped beating him because their arms hurt from hitting. What enraged the victim's parents wasn't the assault itself. They were furious at the shamelessness of the perpetrator parents who said things like "Kids can do that kind of thing" and "Isn't it enough to pay for medical expenses?" One grandmother even came to the victim's house and caused a scene, saying "Are you going to ruin my grandson's future?"

Various analyses emerge regarding the causes of bullying and violence, but we cannot help but point to the side effects of competition-oriented college entrance exam education. The story goes that students stressed by academic burden and college entrance exam competition find an outlet by ostracizing classmates and assaulting juniors. However, school violence is also prevalent in Europe and America, where competitive education is less intense. Cho Byeok, Dongguk University distinguished professor who took on the role of chairman of the School Violence Eradication Advisory Committee, said in his book: "While they say schools have collapsed in Korea, we still hear 'ding-dong-ding' of the school bell. In contrast, in America, we hear 'bang-bang-bang' of school guns."

Parental Selfishness of "Only My Child Is Precious"

The most important yet deliberately ignored aspect is the absence of dinner table education—that is, family education. It seems there are quite a few mothers and fathers who think that sending children to good hagwons and earning good money for them constitutes the entirety of loving their children. On top of this, parents' selfishness and double standards—like "when I do it, it's romance; when others do it, it's adultery"—saying "when my child gets beaten, it's violence; when my child beats others, it's just kids playing around"—are making the situation worse.

Along with schools, families are also primary responsible parties for bullying and violence. The time children spend at school is less than half of what they spend at home. And one teacher is responsible for more than 30 students. They say children grow up watching their parents' backs, but some mothers apparently shout 'Fighting!' when sending their children to school. What exactly are they telling them to fight for? The uncomfortable truth is that behind the educational field that has turned into a jungle, there are parents who push their children to 'win' rather than teaching them 'how to live together.' Of course, the responsibility of the state and society for children who cannot receive care due to family breakdown and poverty should not be diminished either."

Several parents are expressing dissatisfaction with the 'giftedness assessment' that serves as the gifted education center selection exam.

The gifted education center admission process is as follows: The first and second rounds proceed as 'observation-based selection' where homeroom teachers, subject teachers, and principals at each school observe the student's behavior and thought processes for three months.
