○ Overcome the disadvantage of time management

Repeat test-takers have more time flexibility to prepare for the CSAT compared to high school seniors. This is why the general analysis suggests repeat test-takers have an advantage in regular admissions or early admissions with high CSAT weighting.

However, repeat test-takers are at a disadvantage in time management compared to high school seniors. Schools have class schedules and students take midterm and final exams according to predetermined subjects and scope, so they don't need to create separate study plans. Repeat test-takers must organize all their study plans themselves.

Repeat test-taker Kim Dong-young (19) had received first-grade marks in math and science during his high school senior year and set an entrance strategy to aim for early priority selection at Yonsei University and Korea University. However, after receiving below-expected scores on the CSAT and failing admission, he decided to retake. He said, "Overestimating myself too much was the cause of failure," and as a result of dedicating himself to studying, he gained admission to his target program, Materials Science and Engineering at Yonsei University.

Kim calculated his available self-study time on a weekly basis and distributed it by subject. He typically allocated 5 hours on weekdays and 10 hours on weekends for self-study, dividing the total 45 hours by subject area according to his problem-solving speed.

He often divided the time as follows: 15 hours for Korean language, and 10 hours each for mathematics, foreign language, and inquiry subjects. For Korean language, his weak subject, he set aside 3 hours specifically for organizing wrong-answer notes, and on weekends he also scheduled time for taking practice tests. When he occasionally felt exhausted, he would meet and hang out with friends. Time lost to playing was always made up the following week.

Kim said, "Since I know my problem-solving speed best, it's important to adjust study volume according to that speed."

○ Restrain yourself

Another weakness of repeat test-takers is weak binding force. In school, students receive guidance from teachers and take exams at regular intervals. Even if repeat test-takers attend hagwons [private academies], they can skip classes or quit at will. Without strong willpower, it's difficult to consistently maintain test-preparation life.

Repeat test-taker Choi Kyung-seok (20) used methods to restrain himself to avoid becoming lazy. When he first attended a hagwon, he often wasted time sitting in front of the computer after coming home. Thinking this wouldn't work, he left home and lived in a goshiwon [small residential room] near the hagwon. He repeated a lifestyle of studying until 11 PM, then sleeping in the goshiwon and studying at the hagwon from 6:30 AM.

He said, "During my high school senior year, I was lucky to get good practice test scores once. I think becoming lazy from that point was the cause of failure," adding "I was most wary of becoming mentally lax."

He studied basic concept books from the beginning and read 5 Korean language passages every morning. During morning hours when he studied best, he intensively studied Korean language and foreign language, his weak subjects. Choi said, "During my high school senior year, I focused on solving all problems, but during my repeat year, I focused on figuring out knowledge related to the problems—that was the biggest difference."

In the 2011 CSAT, Choi's Korean language and mathematics were only 4th grade, but in 2012 his Korean language, mathematics, and foreign language all became 1st grade. He is waiting for Seoul National University admission results while having already been accepted to Korea University.

○ Maintain study rhythm until the end

If repeat test-takers lose concentration during their repeat year, their grades tend not to rise but fall as the CSAT approaches. According to entrance exam specialists, repeat test-takers show marked grade improvement after the March mock evaluation. However, the upward trend slows from after the September mock evaluation and actually declines. In contrast, most high school seniors maintain consistent study rhythm from March until the CSAT, so sudden grade drops at the last minute are rare.

Choi said, "After September, I felt I had completed my targeted studying and had nothing left to do."

To maintain consistent study rhythm, from September onward he continuously solved final problem sets while timing himself and re-solved past exam questions. He also set a goal of reviewing EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] materials five times per book and continued studying until the end.

Repeat test-takers also have the weakness of experiencing difficulties in relationships with people around them. Having already experienced failure, they easily develop an inferiority complex. They may create conflicts with colleagues or family members sharing the repeat test-taker life, or fall into relationships or drinking.

Many test-takers feel great psychological burden about failure and cannot concentrate on studying, or face physical limitations. Particularly if grades drop in summer when June mock evaluation results come out, it can lead to a slump.

Son Eun-jin, executive director at Megastudy, advised, "Repeat test-taker life doesn't unconditionally lead to success. To succeed, the purpose for retaking must be clear, and willpower to cut off bad habits is necessary.""

Early admissions had expanded so much that she couldn't understand what was what, and even the homeroom teacher told her to write the teacher recommendation letter at home. The director of a company he contacted after seeing an advertisement on an internet cafe claimed, "I've been managing early study abroad students for over 20 years and have sent them to Yonsei University and Korea University." Questions 21 and 30 were identified as high-difficulty items.

Kim Young-il, director of Kim Young-il Education Consulting, diagnosed, "They differentiated by varying the point allocation for the same questions in Type A and Type B, or by transforming multiple choice to short answer while dealing with the same concepts." Oh Jong-woon, evaluation director at Etoos Cheongsol, predicted, "The Grade 1 cutline by type is probably around 92 points for both Type A and Type B."

If this trend continues, many science track test-takers may switch to Mathematics Type A in the actual CSAT, while Type B test-takers could be very few. If this happens, the variable is that Type B test-takers could receive quite low grades despite receiving similar raw scores.

○ English... Largest difficulty gap between Types A and B
"All aspects including vocabulary usage frequency differentiated" Expected to serve as gauge separating grades 1 and 2

The gap between Type A and Type B was very large. Some high school seniors burst into tears immediately after the English test ended, saying they had botched the Type B test.

The Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation explained their question-setting intent: "We intended to maintain an appropriate level difference between Types A and B. We applied differentiation to all aspects: the ratio of practical English to basic academic English, vocabulary usage frequency numbers, word count per passage, complexity, passage comprehension difficulty, and attractiveness of wrong answer choices."

English school teachers diagnosed that Type B was at a similar or more difficult level compared to last year's Foreign Language section, where perfect scorers fell far short of 1%. They particularly expected that with many high-difficulty questions, it would have a decisive impact on distinguishing between grades 1 and 2. Kim Myung-chan, evaluation director at Jongro Academy, said, "If Type B's difficulty is 100, Type A is about 70."

The fact that identical questions have different point allocations in Type A and Type B also draws attention. For example, among common questions, 2 listening questions and 3 reading questions were worth 3 points in Type A and 2 points in Type B.

Admissions experts predicted that this mock exam would influence mid-level and below test-takers to switch to Type A. This is because if they receive grade 5 or below in Type B, they become too disadvantaged in standard scores and percentiles even when applying to universities that give bonus points for Type B."

{
  "translated_title": "[Exciting Study/Edu Column] Before Retaking, Analyze the Causes of Your CSAT Failure First",
  "translated_text": "Song Jae-yeol, Director of Test Master Study Method Research Institute

Every December, when the 2014 college early admission results are announced and regular admission applications begin, test-takers' joy and sorrow are mixed. Students who passed early admission or received better CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] scores than expected will spend the year-end holidays in high spirits, but those who didn't are likely to finish the year feeling depressed. If there are test-takers who are unwillingly considering retaking [becoming a repeat test-taker after high school graduation to retake CSAT], they should analyze several factors before carefully deciding to retake.

Does attending a famous hagwon guarantee retaking success?

When starting to retake, most test-takers think, 'I'll study harder during my retake year and hit it big on next year's CSAT.' This kind of thinking is extremely emotional and abstract.

What should precede the decision to retake is reflecting on what caused one's failure in college admissions. If you start retaking without properly analyzing how you studied this year and what caused your failure, the possibility of repeating failure is very high.

Most test-takers who decide to retake think they will succeed on the next CSAT by attending famous hagwons and studying, without analyzing themselves. However, among students who studied at famous hagwons, some succeed and some repeat failure. The reason for repeating failure is that they couldn't put what the hagwon taught them into their heads. If thorough analysis of the causes of this year's admissions failure comes first, you can raise learning efficiency and concentration during the retake period and succeed in the next admissions.

Independent retaking should develop problem analysis skills

The methods of retaking can be divided into several types. First, if you received grades of 4th level or below on average on this year's CSAT or think your willpower is lacking, I recommend building foundations at a hagwon near home or a boarding hagwon [residential hagwon where students live on-site]. In this case, it's good to receive systematic classes at the hagwon and study with the goal of achieving 3rd level or above grades through review. However, if you're in the 1st-3rd levels and only diligently attended hagwons during high school or studied at the level of diligently listening to internet lectures, I recommend 'independent retaking' - studying alone without attending hagwons. If you're in the upper ranks but fluctuate between upper-middle ranks without achieving satisfactory grades, it's highly likely because you have sufficient knowledge but lack training in analyzing CSAT problems and then applying knowledge to problems. In this case, establishing the habit of studying alone should be prioritized. Remember that you can expect good grades only by becoming familiar with repeatedly solving problems by type.

You might worry about retaking alone, but if your goal is top-tier universities, you must study a lot on your own for one year and become skillful at analyzing all problems to receive scores close to perfect. Keep in mind that the path to 'CSAT jackpot' lies in studying by yourself.

Song Jae-yeol, Director of Test Master Study Method Research Institute"

{
  "translated_title": "[Fun Learning] Boarding Hagwons Move to Adult Market in Search of 'Blue Ocean'",
  "translated_text": "Reporter Kim Man-sik's School Diary
Recently, boarding hagwons, which were considered the exclusive domain of college entrance exam students, are moving into the adult market. On the 5th, an education company famous for online lectures opened the A boarding hagwon dedicated to PEET (Pharmacy Education Eligibility Test) in Yongin, Gyeonggi Province [a city southeast of Seoul]. This is the first adult-targeted boarding hagwon in Korea. A hagwon famous for police civil service exam preparation is also planning to open the B boarding hagwon with a capacity of 1,000 students by acquiring a 4-year university campus in Andong, North Gyeongsang Province.

Amidst a prolonged recession where many education companies are struggling, why are they entering the adult-targeted boarding hagwon market that requires substantial initial investment costs? Industry insiders cite higher profitability compared to operating boarding hagwons for college entrance exam students as the primary reason.

The A boarding hagwon has a capacity of around 250 students. Compared to the similarly-sized college entrance-focused C boarding hagwon, the number of class hours that determine instructor fees (actual teaching hours that form the basis for calculating instructor compensation) is significantly reduced. The A boarding hagwon's weekly class hours are 32 hours. This is more than 10 hours less compared to the 40-45 hour level of similarly-sized C boarding hagwon. This is due to the difference in the number of subjects for the Pharmacy Education Eligibility Test and CSAT (College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam).

The Pharmacy Education Eligibility Test consists of 4 subjects: △General Physics △General Chemistry △Organic Chemistry △Biology, but CSAT includes △Korean △Mathematics △English △Social Studies (10 subjects) △Science (8 subjects), and even requires essay-writing exam instructors for early admission preparation. Labor costs are reduced compared to operating college entrance boarding hagwons, allowing for relatively higher profit margins.

Additionally, adult-targeted boarding hagwons are free from various regulations under the existing hagwon law. College entrance boarding hagwons are designated as 'school subject tutoring hagwons' that teach students from schools under Article 2 of the 'Elementary and Secondary Education Act' according to hagwon law, and are subject to strict management and supervision by education offices regarding facilities, instructor standards, and tuition setting. However, adult-targeted boarding hagwons are registered as 'lifelong education vocational hagwons' under hagwon law and are not subject to such regulations.

For example, the C boarding hagwon, which is a school subject tutoring hagwon, cannot separately charge membership fees or uniform costs in addition to the monthly tuition of approximately 2.3 million won [approximately $1,750 USD]. However, the A boarding hagwon, which is a lifelong education vocational hagwon, can demand a membership fee of 500,000 won [approximately $380 USD] and separate uniform costs in addition to the monthly tuition of 2.2 million won [approximately $1,675 USD].

Analysis suggests that the recent ease in securing facilities for adult boarding hagwons, which allows for savings in initial investment costs, has also influenced the increase in adult-targeted boarding hagwons.

A boarding hagwon official said, "Recently, quite a few boarding hagwons have closed due to operational difficulties and are on the market, so we don't necessarily need to purchase buildings and can just sign rental contracts," adding "The A boarding hagwon is also using a building through a rental contract. Since there are so many boarding hagwons waiting for owners, education companies can proceed with favorable contracts in the direction they want."

The situation where new markets must be developed as the school-age population decreases is also a factor driving entry into the adult boarding market.

While students taking college entrance exams are decreasing, demand from so-called 'gongsi-jok' [a term referring to civil service exam preparation students] who aim for professional jobs like doctors and pharmacists and stable civil service positions is steadily increasing.

An official from a Pharmacy Education Eligibility Test specialist hagwon in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul] said, "About 15,000 students took the 2014 Pharmacy Education Eligibility Test," adding "The number of test-takers has continued to grow from 10,000 in 2011 when the first test was administered, to 12,194 in 2012, and 13,142 in 2013."

An official from a civil service exam hagwon in Noryangjin [a Seoul district known for civil service exam preparation hagwons] said, "The adult boarding hagwon market has opened as the anxious psychology of job seekers who want to prepare for exams in a more reliable way amid increasingly fierce competition has aligned with the interests of education companies seeking new blue oceans," adding "Depending on the results produced by companies that have just entered the adult-targeted boarding hagwon business, there is a high possibility that third and fourth adult boarding hagwons will emerge.""
}
